description:
Let me caveat this review by saying that I'm not a karaoke aficionado even though I am asian. Singing in front of a large crowd scares the bajeezus out of me, which is why when I get invited to true karaoke spots like Pandora, that's a usual decline on my end.

I took my friend to a nearby Chinatown bar and on our way there we noticed a group of people singing inside Bow Wow. We thought to ourselves, "wow those people actually look like they are having fun." instead of the typical SF bar scene where it's crowded like a tin can of sardines and full of tech bros and tech h... you get the point. Most SF bars I find are clones of one another -- nothing singular about, much like the people of SF -- all Patagucci athleisure-wear dwellers. 

I like Chinatown bars because the true locals come here and those who want to have a more diverse crowd of people. Bow Wow is a simple dive bar with karaoke near the back. It's unapologetic and doesn't try to be something it's not.  

The beers are also stinkin cheap. $10 for 2 beers. Mind you a majority of these patrons were white but I love that they were drinking Tsing Tao or Tiger! And gringos karaoke way harder than asians. When the song "Africa" came on, no one really knew that song it was until the chorus and then we all sang our hearts out. I've never had so much fun karaoking. Music really brings people together and is the glue of our social fabric. Definitely coming back here with my amigos!
author: Connie M.

description:
Very disappointed in this place. I was looking forward to grabbing a few drinks with friends and singing some karaoke. We gave a card to open a tab and were told that there was a $20 minimum for card purchases. This was a little steep but we were planning on having several drinks anyway so we figured it wasn't a problem.

The place was almost empty. This was in the middle of the afternoon on a Sunday and out of maybe 20 or 25 barstools, only 5 were occupied when we came in, all by the same group. Our group of 5 sat on the opposite side of the bar closest to the karaoke. Still plenty of empty seats. 

About midway through our first drinks, the bartender named Cindy made a snark remark to one of my friends for drinking water. We let Cindy know that she was our designated driver and that the rest of our group would drink plenty of drinks to make up for it. This didn't stop her. She proceeded to yell at our group in Cantonese then began talking about us to the other group that was there, all of whom were Chinese. That group then also proceeded to yell at us in Cantonese. One of the members of our group is Chinese and she understood everything they were saying. They called us all sorts of inappropriate names. It was an extremely uncomfortable experience. All of this because our designated driver refused to drink alcohol. 

I understand if there was a line out the door and we were wasting bar space for other paying patrons, but the place was literally empty besides us and that group of 5 people. There was no reason for Cindy to make any comments. Anyone with an ounce of business logic would know she'll make more money with our group there than with our group not there and those seats remaining empty. In addition, what would've been a nice and healthy tip became an average tip.

I see all the reviews about this older Mamma Candy lady and they're all glowing and positive. I think they need to go back to her because Cindy is doing this business no favors.
author: Joshua T.

description:
Went for the first time Sat night 6/23/18 for boyfriend's bday. SO MUCH FUN!!! Everything is true in the reviews!  Great bartender that really pays attention to you, cool atmosphere, super collection of karaoke, and good drinks.  

I kind of don't want to write this because I don't want it to become too crazy crowded!  

Sssshhhhhhh ;-).......
author: Dre C.

description: avoid this place at all costs. female bartender/owner was rude and obnoxious. openly forcing us to buy drinks after saying we did not want any more. one of the worst establishments i have ever been to. would give no stars if possible.  you have been warned
author: Gavin V.

description:
I was walking down from another bar when I heard singing. The singing make me stop and drop in for a beer. Two beers and a shot of henney later, I was singing Aladdin. When I turned around, this crowd of people was behind me. Some Scottish guy came up and took a selfie with me (?) while I sang the chorus. I was a little taken aback, but it was fine. Everyone was a little drunk. My next song, this Vietnamese guy put his arms over my shoulders and tried to sing the NSync song with me. I nudged him away and he backed off, but a few moments later, decided to get touchy again. Aside from those two awkward experiences, I had a good time. 

Would I go back? Probably after a few drinks.
author: Sam Y.

description:
It's really nice to know that places like this still exist in San Francisco. I hadn't been to Bow Bow in a number of years and was recently in the neighborhood so, thought...why not? Upon entering, I was greeted by a nice cloud of cigarette smoke and for some reason it made me happy to know that someone had just finished smoking a dart. Old school. 

After ordering a vodka soda from Mama Candy, I promptly peeled open the karaoke book and found my song. The bar was empty aside from a few friends I was with so, anything was fair game. Naturally I started with a classic by the Backstreet Boys, and followed it up with a Kenny Rogers tune, "The Gambler". Nailed em both...

Check Bow Bow out if you're a fan of dives and San Francisco gems.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
MAMA CANDY!

That is all your really need to know. Looking for a good time? Come in on a Friday or Saturday night. Mama Candy will take care of you!
This hole in the wall is awesome. Total dingy, amazing dive bar. There is karaoke, nice little plus. The people who come here all know Mama and love her, for a reason. She's a badass. Such a little spitfire and for an older women, she'll knock you on your ass! She loves Patron Silver, keep that in mind! It will benefit you in the long run.

Came here for the second time last SF trip. So glad we did. It was nice to have a little home away from home. LOVE YOU MAMA!
author: Zoe F.

description:
1 word..... maybe 2.
MAMA CANDY.
enough said - place has so much spirit and good vibes.
cant say anything bad about this place - total dive bar - the ultimate dive bar.
karaoke, cocaine residue, and cheap drinks - i loved it... literally felt like i was at home.

Mama Candy was so sweet and funny and just all around a bad ass!!! 
LOVE YOU MAMA CANDY!
author: Steve S.

description:
High end would definitely be low on my list in terms of how to describe Bow Bow - but tons of fun is near the top! This is a great dive to enjoy some cheap drinks/beers, and Mama is super friendly and  welcoming! 

The karaoke is the icing on the cake - good selection, and the cheesy videos make it even more fun. The lack of a stage also adds to the environment and encourages bar-wide participation. Definitely a fun place for a relaxed night.
author: Holly L.

description: Such a horrible experience the 2 times I visited. I thought the 1st time was a bad day for the bar tender, Cindy. But she was just as rude and racist making bad comments in chinese about my daughter  because she was only drinking water. Saying she is wasting the bars space...and the bar only had another 4 or 5 patrons. She also incited the locals saying racist comments and did not realize my girlfriend speaks fluent mandarin and Cantonese and is actually chinese, last name Xu. When my gf spoke up she then made nagative comments about her being with an American. I do business and have supported the Asian community for more then 20 years, I am a member of Asian Real Estate Association of America and Chinese Real Estate Association among others. I was in the area for the Miss Asian Global Pageant as a sponsor. That should tell you how wrong she was threatening us that the chinese in the area wouldnt want us back. I will take this up with the Chamber and the owner as we need to rid the great community of China Town of these classless people who reverse all the amazing accomplishments we have all realized together.
author: Respectfully Yours Y.

description:
This is one of my favorite gems of the city. Mama is wonderful and you need to just drink what she gives you and say thanks. 
Every time my friends come to visit we go sing at Mama's place.
author: Mikey P.

description:
Divey as fuck. If you come here super plastered, you'd feel like you time-traveled somewhere. Actually, I was sober and felt that way. As my fiance said, this place is Christmas and New Year's at the same time. They haven't taken down their decorations in probably years, but it's part of the charm. I love Christmas string lights! How mesmerizing!

I came really early (like 7) on a Friday night and there were only a few people. It would be an awesome place to drop in when it gets busier and seeing people sing their hearts out to karaoke with, yes, the weird 80s stock video in the background.

Drinks are alright. But the complimentary snacks doe? Mama Candy hooked it up with free roasted peanuts and pistachios. DOWNNNN.
author: Emily C.

description: Just a downright fun bar.  The bartender was so fun, cool and sweet. Crowd was very happy and the karaoke was all about fun!  Fun song selections and no great singers but everyone was singing at the top of their lungs!  So much fun!  Would definitely recommend and go back!
author: Joe C.

description: This was the best bar experience of my life. Mama Candy will literally take care of you at the bar. Highly recommend visiting the bar if you want to learn a thing or two about karaoke and life.
author: Akshaya M.

description: Alright, I'm a fan. It's about as divey as you get in here - the lighting is dim, there's no tap, bathrooms are single stall, and there's just enough space for the bar counter and a single walker to head to the bathroom. But, what can I say? I'm a sucker for a straight dive, and there aren't that many left. Sure, there are no taps, and liquor selection is limited, but you have what you need, and drinks are cheap. The bartender (Momma) also pushes drinks your way and feeds you plenty of free peanuts and pistachios.  Honestly, you just don't get this kind of vibe anymore in San Francisco. There are two tvs (one with a game, the other with some sort of Asian pop music), and karaoke blasts throughout at night. I'll be back.
author: Danny C.

description: MaMA Candie (S) PLural.....all you need to know! Most legit place if you want a real, authentic experience.  You can walk into empty bar, walk out full bar of friends.  AMAZING Spot nd you never know what you are going to get.  The whole family is amazing. A+ love that places like this still exist....#chinatown
author: Ellie J.

description: Could not even order a drink as the bartender was linguistically challenged. Didn't know what a Bahamas mamma or peach schnapps was.
author: Todd W.

description: One of my favorite karaoke places in the city. So yeah, maybe the song versions are a little "off" sometimes, and the videos are your standard random karaoke clips of people running on beaches and occasionally crying for an unknown reason. But who cares? Cheap drinks (especially for the city and for North Beach), and a non-judgy place to sing (badly?) to your heart's content - exactly what a karaoke dive should be.
author: Erin E.

description: In a ever changing City, I appreciate gems like this. I hope my daughter someday has a drink served by Candy!
author: Jo J.

description: Did not get a good vibe from the bartender on a Thursday afternoon. Felt that she was needlessly rude and dismissive. The beer was cheap and cold, hence the 2 stars. That still couldn't get me to stay and Finnish my beer.
author: Moeketsi M.

description: This a dive bar with a Chinese flare. The bartender Mama Candy made the whole experience much more fun. Great place to hangout and if you have had one too many you can sing some karaoke!
author: Angela R.

description: This place is a gem and Mama Candy is the best bartender ever! This karaoke bar is small and cozy and Mama tends to you and makes sure you are neither hungry nor thirsty. Colorful Christmas string lights illuminate the place and give it a red glow, 80s/90s karaoke songs play in the background, the place is always filled with interesting people, and after you sit down you just forget where you are. Good vibes all around!
author: Beata G.

description:
I appreciate bars of all shapes and sizes but in the category of Dive bars there might be no better than this gem of a dive in the heart of Chinatown. The other spots down the street get all the hype(Li Po and Buddha) and deservedly so, though I will argue Li Po has fallen, more on that later.. This should all be about Bow Bow which should translate to Miss Candy's 15 seats of joy and happiness. 

As you've probably seen from all the other reviews there is no bartender more revered than Mama Candy and when you meet her you'll feel the same way.  Sure you might at first glance make fun of her look or her accent but if you do you'll regret it once she welcomes you with open arms. If she doesn't do it with her charm she'll do it with her whiskey or complimentary nuts (no pun intended). 

On top of having an amazing bartender which is always a pre-requisite for every elite dive bar. They have the other two covered (in my opinion) which is bad lighting for selfies and complimentary snacks you'd never eat anywhere else. Her pistachios keep you drinking till you forget what time you even walked in there. Like a Vegas casino you get transported away from everything you know in life to get wrapped up in the world of Bow Bow or what some people call "Candyland"

Did I mention there was karaoke too? BONUS
author: Joco F.

description: This is the epitome of a dive bar. Momma (the owner) is a good time. Nothing fancy, but good times. No food and no champagne, but lots of fireball.
author: Kristen H.

description: I haven't seen. Mamma in about 6 months. I was in china town looking for a new suite case. ... Momma is only working the weekends .. I said why not stop in..love this lady . Love this place.. I told momma I was going to Yelp 5 stars .. She said no please only 4.. Come in get  a drink. Buy momma a tequila !
author: Jason P.

description:
I've come to the Bow Bow Lounge a few times and have always had a blast.
Yes it's divey, and yes it's dimly lit and a little grungy - but the drinks are cheap and the bartenders are awesome!
Sign yourself for Karaoke, grab a drink, and have a good time!
author: Michelle L.

description: Me and my BFF just had to do karaoke our first night in San Francisco. It's unlike any karaoke venue I've ever been to yes it's crowded yes everyone grabs for the mic and sings along but it just seems to work here. Mama Kandy was very nice and helpful very personable and the place was packed it's in Chinatown and we had a blast! Everyone here was super friendly!
author: Kat O.

description:
Mama Candy holds down the fort here! This bar is a little hard to find as it's tucked away in an alley in Chinatown. Not an ideal place to take your date to, but a good place to sing karaoke and have some carefree fun. Don't let the looks of this quirky dive bar fool you. Mama Candy will take care of you and will make sure you have a great time. Just don't forget to return the favor and buy her some patron shots. 

The place looks a little rundown and the drinks are nothing special, but her hospitality makes up for it. Throughout the night, she generously poured us shots after shots and even served us peanuts and pistachios. Not sure how she can make a profit by giving those out for free...
author: Helen C.

description:
Hey, do you like cheap drinks and amazing karaoke? Do you like weird, janky places? Are you a weird, janky person like me? (You probably are.) Bow Bow is probably the place for you.

Great karaoke on the single screen in the back of the bar which is (apparently) always on, cheap drinks, and a basically infinite supply of bar peanuts and pistachios. 

Just make sure not to skip a song that one of the bartenders put on-- they're amazing karaoke performers.
author: Jim M.

description:
This looks like a place straight out of a movie. Forget your swanky lounges in SoMa, this place is unique, quirky, gritty, divey, and has character, and is also tucked away on the outskirts of Chinatown. You could blink and miss it, but it's right off of Broadway. If you're tired of paying $12-14 for cocktails at a lounge in North Beach, come into this place for inexpensive drinks, karaoke and complimentary peanuts and pistachios.

It wasn't super crowded when we came here on a Saturday night, but it's pretty long and narrow, so it's not great if you come with 6+ people, since you will be either in the back by the karaoke, or towards the door and it may be hard to all talk. Also, probably not the best for a first date.

There is only one bartender (Candy), who I also think owns the place - she will tell it like it is, pour you a stiff drink, and if it's your birthday, she may give you a free shot of Patron and take one herself (at least this was the case for my friend). 

If you want to come hang out with a group of friends for a low-key, unique experience that is a bit off the beaten path, come here for a fun night. Make sure to do some karaoke, and bring cash, since they don't take credit cards.
author: Christina L.

description: A literal tiny hole-in-the wall dive bar in Chinatown, but the bartender boss lady and I go way back. I've been a good handful of times to sing my one token Chinese song, The Moon Represents My Heart a la 1960s Teresa Teng, as well as drink stiff Long Islands and shell peanuts. I've even been on a date and imbibed so much I accidentally smashed my cocktail glass against the bar and had to get carried out. Boss Lady and her infamous scratchy sultry smoker's voice still forgave me.
author: Christina S.

description:
Whoever labeled BowBow a "dive bar in Chinatown" got it right. It is. But, it is also a fun place to stop for a drink or two.

PROS: Mama Candy; karaoke; festive place for a group

CONS: cash only, and you pay when you order. 

Again, this place is a dive bar.  Probably best as a stop on a pub crawl.  Mama Candy is a hoot, but I'm guessing you don't want to see her bad side. That said, she bought our group a round of shots during our BDay celebration, so we're fans.

Cheers!
RS
author: Rich S.

description:
Ok, I confess - I'm a karaoke junkie! I'll go months without doing it, without realising what I'm missing, then one day the opportunity comes up and I'll move hell and high water to get there!

After eating more heavenly Indian food that I thought physically possible we took a trip to Bow Bow "cocktail" "lounge." The drinks are generously called cocktails, and it's not very loungey, but what it is is a perfect, tiny, skinny dive bar filled with old Chinese men playing dice, and a karaoke machine. 

We had some ok drinks and flipped through the karaoke books - unfortunately they didn't have my song (Love is a Battlefield) but they did have some other gems. Yes. I sang Mama Mia and I have no regrets!

After a few songs we convinced the owner to give us a song and were totally blown away! Seriously, ask her to sing and you will Bow Bow down to the master!!
author: Ayla C.

description: Flabbergasted as to how this place is continually referred to as a dive bar. If by "dive bar" you  mean slightly grungy in appearance but filled with tech bros, then sure. There is no regulation of the karaoke music. Anyone can use the remote to put in music, which means that self-entitled people regularly skip other people's songs to try to get to theirs sooner. Very disappointed
author: Sarah C.

description: Tiny little spot, pool table and amazing cocktails, beer on tap very good with an excellent selection of bottled beers. Got there for happy hour. The bartenders weren't the nicest or friendliest but not out right rude either.
author: Ali B.

description: I almost didn't give this place a review because I don't want anyone else to know about it. This is the best place to do karaoke in SF, hands down... if you're in to weird experiences. LOVE this place.
author: Carissa H.

description:
I imagine Bow Bow might be completely unbearable when you're not in the right frame of mind. However, if you've spent the earlier part of your evening in the company of bartenders and essentially main-lined whiskey for the better part of five hours, there's no better place in the world. 

The joint is run by Mama Candy. She is surprisingly jovial for someone who has to deal with the most intolerable karaoke singing known to man. From what I can tell, Mama Candy and I are exactly alike. How, you ask? Here's five reasons:

1. Much like myself, She doesn't sing, she just drinks.

2. If you're buying a round of shots in her vicinity, you have to buy her one too. I think that's a good rule when it comes to me too. 

3. I hear she can be a bit aggressive at times (a friend of mine may or may not have gotten in a fistfight with Mama Candy at one point, but they are cool now). Sometimes I fly off the handle. You don't even know about me.

4. She will simultaneously scold you for not ordering enough booze, but also insist that you drink another glass of water. Drunk, but hydrated; that's my motto.

5. You'll never win an argument against either of us. She will throw you out of the bar at 2 am. But even if you point out that her clock is 20 minutes fast and that it's only 1:40 am, you're still wrong.

Basically identical twins. If you're in SF and I'm not, just go chill at Bow Bow. I'll be with you in spirit.
author: Peter D.

description: Super awesome local "dive"!!  Everyone was great..once we got Kareoke rocking place filled up quick..lil small but comfy..cheap drinks..great service and just quirky enough to be charming.  We are from Phoenix AZ.
author: Steven K.

description: Mama is the best! This place is small, but awesome. Mama takes good care of you and you even get snacks when you order a drink. I always feel at home here. Best public karaoke in SF.
author: Crystal J.

description:
Um... yeah. 

Tiny little dive.
A karaoke list that's both short and disorganized.
Mama Candy. 

You have to experience it to believe it.
author: Don B.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE Mama Candy. By far she is the best in China Town!! We found her bar in September 2009 on one of our visits to the city. She bought us shots and bought us the best bbq pork from next door. Her hospitality and friendliness had us swearing to return. 

We finally found our way back to her and had an absolute blast again. Where we're from bars don't provide endless pistachios with your beer. Plus where else can you find an Asian bar-owner in Chinatown that only drinks PATRON!! LOL. Mama Candy is awesome! It's a casual place with karaoke every night.

If ever in China Town visit Mama Candy!!
author: Mrs P.

description: We spent our Christmas Eve with Mama Candy. A group of us decided Christmas with our respective families, and all the trimmings, was horribly overrated. I know, I know, it's all about family, but go humbug yourself, we're family now.  We stumbled into this gem of an establishment and took away cheer, stories, and an understanding that sometimes, when you pick a song, there will be no lyrics. Also, sometimes the lyrics aren't super accurate, which makes it even better. Mama was a consummate host, quick with a drink and a smile, and is now a friend...baby.
author: Michael B.

description:
Was here about 11 pm on Sat/4 Jul:
- $7 per Jack & Coke, made pretty strong.
- Karaoke system that's multi-lingual (1 song was sung in Chinese).
- Great bartender, complimentary peanuts (still in their shells so more sanitary than eating shelled peanuts from communal bowls).
- Docked 1 star because poor ventilation, really need at least a fan to vent the closed end of the bar.
author: Chan L.

description:
I came here for a friends surprise birthday party.. When I walked in, I was less than thrilled. The place is pretty tiny, and not much room for the elaborate dance moves I planned on busting during my karaoke solos. But, I gave it a shot, and fell in love. 

I forget her name, but our bartender was the sweetest. She let our party hide behind the bar as the guest of honor walked in, and we surprised her perfectly! I was pretty shocked that a bartender allowed strangers behind the bar. But, she loved the idea and was more than willing. She even banged the dong when we yelled surprise! 

Drinks are okay, nothing to write home about, but the ambiance and customer service really makes up for that aspect. 

If you're wondering, I did Lucky by Ms. Britney Spears, and completely brought down the house.
author: Alex G.

description:
What an absolute trip, The Bow Wow! 
This gritty lil place is a popular hoot for karaoke aficionados who don't mind a little chaos in the mix. I'm making this a frequent stop on nights out in the city when I lead a group. 
The expectations are low and the fun factor is high!

Mama Candy forked over the controls and let me run my folks, awesome! 
Someone unknown to me mirrored 3 of my songs within 15 minutes of me singing them (who does THAT?) and butchered em, making me look like a rock star! Weird and wonderful!

I, in reaction, sang Pearl Jam's 'Alive' twice in a row and nobody cared.

Some dude who spoke no English befriended me, we became fast friends, hugging us at every turn all night long. 
We had lots to say but spoke only two words in common, "Happy," "Yes!"
It went on and on, hugs, Happy, Yes, hugs, Yes, Happy!!

We sang and partied, danced and hugged. We had intimate conversations completely not understood. The lyrics were off, the song numbers often wrong, the singing off-key, the decibels to the moon. It was all so loud and manic and wild. The smell of cheap beer and sticky icky permeated the joint. Drunken cheers and crazed vocals filled the air. And some real talent too!

Quite the vibrant night in Chinatown. Can't wait to go back. 
Happy, Yes, Happy!!
author: Jimmy F.

description: Random stop on santa con night, awesome time, drinks were fast and mama was sweet. Karaoke was a blast, kinda unorganized but still good times!
author: Roberta C.

description:
One of the hardest things about growing older is having to let go of the magic of our childhoods.  We have to trade our Heelys for sensible cap toe oxfords.  We have to trade our wizard wands and lightsabers for 401Ks and mortgages.  We have to trade our fairy tale endings for the deepening sense that maybe the best years of our lives are already over.  

Once in a while, if we're very lucky, something or someone will bring that spark of magic back to life.  We start to believe again in a brighter, happier future.  We start to think maybe good things do happen to good people.  We start to wonder if North Korea isn't all just some kind of obscene practical joke started by the South Koreans.

Going to Bow Bow Cocktail Lounge brought that magic back into my life last night.  As soon as I walked into that tight, cramped space and was blasted in the face with the overpowering smell of incense, I knew I was home.  

Bow Bow is a dive bar, but it's so much more than that.  It's hallowed ground, run by a wonderful woman named Mama Candy (I believe it's a self-chosen nickname) who throws down absurdly cheap drinks with a heavy hand and a crooked smile.  Every drink is accompanied by a bowlful of peanuts and a plate full of pistachios.  I have no fucking idea how she makes any money at all, given how ludicrously expensive pistachios are.  

The walls are full of random Chinatown bric-a-brac, the lights are dim and neon-lit, and everyone inside is having the time of their lives.  This is all helped by an old-school karaoke machine in the back, which comes with terrific 90s stock footage of white people running on the beach and looking at each other.  

This is a place where dreams really do come true, provided your dream is to sing a loud and off-key version of "I Wanna Dance With Somebody" to a room full of judgmental strangers
author: Kevin C.

description: Very small bad but the lady bartender was very nice and the prices were good.  She gave us pistachios.  Apparently they have Kareoke on Saturday nights.  I would have liked to have stayed and sang a little song.. but the thought of me singing scared my husband right out of the joint!
author: Lauren E.

description:
This is such a random great time! Bring your favorite karaoke song in your head because you will be tempted to sing!! Very friendly atmosphere.. NO PRESSURE!! 
I RECOMMEND!!
author: Laurry W.

description:
What can I say about Bow Bow other than that it feels like home. 

I stumbled into Bow Bow after a typical, sticky North Beach night of pure degeneracy, and have kept coming back since. Bow Bow has been owned for 30 years by the legend and San Francisco institution known as Mama Candy. I have personally witnessed her fall asleep at cash registers, open beer bottles with knives, and cajole me into buying her probably $200 of Patron shots over the last few months. 

There's also a karaoke machine in the back. If you ever hear the golden words "you a son of mama" uttered here, you've made it in San Francisco
author: Aaron V.

description:
The kinda disorganized, details-be-damned attitude at Bow Bow was kinda cool when we first started our after-party but then got progressively more annoying as the night went on.

Mama Candy is very friendly and, in this tiny bar, gives everyone plenty of personal attention, winks, smiles and hand waves.  That's all cool and super lovely UNTIL you want to sing your heart out.  The machine she has set up plays a guessing game with your selections.  Maybe it will come out in English, maybe in Catonese and maybe not at all.  Mama Candy don't care.  She would literally just shimmy shimmy her way through the bar and do one of these dramatic dame hand waves, like "Who Cares, Daaahling?"  I care, dahling.  My crew and I wanted to sing.

So, at any rate, it's a fun tiny bar for bar hopping but definitely not a final destination.  Plan accordingly.
author: Alina M.

description:
Mama Candy knows what's up here. 

She made the most amazing "special cocktail" for me. I saw her make it and she must have poured a good 10 different things into it. It was made with true love and care and presented beautifully in a martini glass. Class, I tell you.

Not to mention that my water glass was never empty throughout the evening. Both Mama Candy and the vocally talented bartender beside her - made sure that I was constantly hydrated throughout the evening.

My favorite aspect of this intimate and quirky karaoke bar - is that people take their karaoke with a smile. There's none of the ego and edge that some of the other karaoke stops in the city have. Just pure fun and good times.

Oh and though they don't carry Rich Girl here in their song selection - they have my close second favorite - karaoke number - Danny's Song by Kenny Loggins.

So what's up.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
15 Romolo? Eh. Comstock Saloon? Yawn. Tope? Boring.

Bow Bow? New favorite bar in North Beach/Chinatown!

Waxing poetic seems fruitless, as there's only one name you need to know to ensure you have a remarkable time in this rathskeller of a karaoke den/dive bar: Mama Candy. She's the Mandarin mother I never had!

Watch out for those pistachio shells -- they're slippery little buggers!
author: Ruggy J.

description: Now this is a true karaoke gem. It's tiny - tiny, tiny, tiny - a complete dive with a friendly (and sassy) barkeep properly named Mama Candy. It doesn't get better than this, kids. No, really. The song list is out of alphabetical order, the restrooms are questionable, and the AV system is a tad janky. But regardless, you and your crew will have a BLAST. Trust me ... I have video to prove it.
author: Farrah A.

description: Insane hole in the wall dive . no room no A/C and NO karaoke host. People just  grab the Karaoke remote and plug in the  song they want no law n order here and its a  blast!!!
author: Ken S.

description: Such a good time here! I realized after an hour that Mama Candy was the only one that actually worked there. Karaoke was so much fun even though it didn't always have the words up on the screen. Everyone felt like family after a few rounds.
author: Kim P.

description: This is such a fun place to pregame/postgame. Mama, the bartender/manager/owner?, is hilarious and so entertaining. The place is pretty small, so I'd recommend you go with 4 people or less. There is just one TV and karaoke mic for the entire bar. I went around 9pm so the karaoke part wasn't really happening, which was kind of a bummer. I'm sure the later you go, the more poppin it'll be. Honestly, I'd just come here for Mama!
author: Divya A.

description:
If Bow Bow were a person, I would say "I love you. Why do you keep hurting me?"

Unless you're a huge drinker, the legendary Mama will be an enormous b*tch to you. Not in a sassy, entertainingly b*tchy way, either. More like a wow, what an incredibly unpleasant woman, how does she still have a job kind of way. The drinks aren't particularly cheap (I think Anchor Steam is $6), and it's the absolute worst song book in the city. Mama has been known to coerce drunks into paying for her drinks. You have to stand right by the bathroom door to perform. So why do I go there?

Because if you get there early enough in the evening, Mama isn't there. Because in those early evening hours, especially on weekdays, you'll find older men singing "He's Not Heavy, He's My Brother" in a barely intelligible manner, but with all the feeling you could possibly give that song. Because they have quite the selection of outdated Chinese propaganda ballads, and I like the videos of the patriotic factory worker longing for her soldier boyfriend. Because I like danger, and when the songbook says "Creep" but doesn't say whether it's TLC or Radiohead, you're really taking a chance (it's TLC, by the way).

So, yes, I love Bow Bow. And yes, I take people there to sing and listen. But I cannot give it 5 stars.
author: Annelise D.

description:
Stuck in traffic with my little cousins.

Turns on cd player.

Teresa Teng - Tian Mi Mi                      "NEXT!"
Jacky Cheung - Everlasting Love        "NEXT!"

Ok maybe they are more Americanized than I thought.

Nirvana - smells like spirit.    "WAIT!"

They grab my aux jack and plug in an iPhone.

*bubble butt, bubble, bubble, bubble butt*

Is this generation really listening to this?
I've literally died and went to H E double hockey stick.


Why do I like bow bow and feel like I'm at home here? Its simple the music. Old school canto pop and mandarin songs all day. I'm an old soul. Music that is simple and evokes emotions is my cup of tea. One of the bartender sings so elegantly too. It brings back memories of my dad playing his old cassettes loudly when mom wasn't home. The vibe is chill and once in awhile you get some white folks screaming living on a prayer. It's cool with me! Candy I love your bar.

Now back to traffic.

"Guys WTH was that? We are going to have a music lesson in Uncle Kwangto's car!"

Grabs an Anita Mui collection and Too $hort greatest hits CDs.

*You should be gettin it, everything you want, everything you dreamed of, never have to front* 

And the heads are bobbing in the rear view mirror.
author: Q L.

description:
I love MAMA CANDY!! She's amazingly funny, and makes killer drinks.

I would recommend getting her special mai tais - It's topped with a secret ingredient... Some kind of Chinese whiskey. If you ask Mama Candy, she'll let you in on the secret. ;)

They have karaoke and yummy bar snacks. Candy's super sweet (pun intended!) and fun to talk to. She said she opened the bar 27 years ago to the month! That's longer than I have been alive. 

There's an old guy who's usually in there who speaks Cantonese (far as I can tell he speaks primarily Cantonese, with some very broken English sprinkled in) that will challenge you to a game of dice for drinks. He's great to talk to as well and I was sad I didn't get to see my buddy last time I went in. Next time, Old Chinese Guy!!!
author: Lynn H.

description:
This decor is dark and intimate but the attitude is loud and outgoing. 

If the heavy handed pours by the super friendly barkeep don't keep you here the good conversation and free snacks sure will. Fully stocked bar and a good selection domestic beers all served with a smile at a great price. 

Need a jump-off point for a night on the town? This could be your joint.
author: Justin C.

description:
" bow bow  "                  the home of.              " mama.     candys  "


                            " chinese  flaming.   lemon.  drops "


                    kareoke. music  begins  at.   9 p m.     everynight !!!



          come join us.        bring.  your.  crazy.    talented.  friends. !!!!




                                           
                            in. the. heart. of. chinatown . !!!
author: EILEEN M.

description:
I'm kinda torn as to how to rate this place. The karaoke is tops in the city. Most of the songs are bootlegs and whoever transcribed the lyrics made plenty of mistakes. 

The few drinks I've ordered here were definitely watered down, so stick to beer, which is expensive for a spot like this. Take this how you want, bit there appears to be tiered pricing based on who mama candy is serving. 

Bonus that you can smoke inside, even though I'm a non-smoker
author: Chaz G.

description:
For the first three hours we were here it was great. The bartender was very friendly and encouraging ... she kept telling us to choose songs and sing. The bar tab for three hours and six people was around $110 before tip, which was great.

Then there was the shift change .... dun dun dun.

The new bartender was the worst I may have ever had.

At this point we are all singing in unison and having a great time.

Without explanation she cuts the music... We start rumbling and then she tosses different books of songs on the bar and says "pick from here." Those were the first and last words she said to us the whole time. Not "good evening" or "would you like a drink." 

The book she gave was 10X worse than the other one. No artists. No organization. 

It certainly seemed like she was doing her very best to get us to leave. It worked and I'm pissed. 

I'll never go back here, which is a shame because up until the shift change it was a pleasant experience.
author: Angela M.

description: drink before dinner...walk along chinatown...bow bow cocktail lounge....a small dive bar appearance with higher prices...$five typical beers...quick id check, for others..."no id check for chinese," told...assume small joke...older chinese gentleman walking back to a random karaoke machine...loud screech from the speakers...horrible sound layout...screech!...but, entertaining bartender... some nuts with $five heineken...special pistachio and peanuts..."for chinese only," told...final cheers and to dinner...self not chinese, but korean...
author: Hen A.

description:
walk up in the club like "UNAPOLOGETICALLY SING THE LONG VERSION OF PURPLE RAIN"

Wake up in the afternoon somewhere in north beach, still drunk. 
 
there are no words
author: John X.

description:
We had a blast here!  Randomly stumbled in during Chinese New Year.  Mama was awesome (the bartender), the karaoke was hilarious, and the owner was there drinking the top shelf stuff.  Someone gave us fireworks (not sure that's a great plan?).

If I lived in SF, this would be my regular.
author: Ellie F.

description:
Went here for the 2nd time and had fun again. 
It is a tiny bar with Karaoke. It's really dark and the drinks are a bit watered down (but what bar's drinks aren't watered down?) but we have fun every time we go there. The owner is a sweet lady (which is the main reason to go there). Be sure to do the Karaoke... the videos are CRAZY and sometimes the lyrics are wrong, but you will have a really fun time!
author: Dawn R.

description: Best dive bar ever! Owners are super nice and totally let us take over the karaoke machine. Great times!
author: Catherine C.

description:
What can I say? It's small, has alcohol, karaoke is great, middle aged chinese men hilariously throwing down in the back, the two hispanic guys that puked into the bowl of peanuts, that and Mama Candy is awesome. 

Drink a lot and often, drinks are somewhat light.
author: Wilson T.

description:
This is the joint where you come to slam a few shots back...muster up some courage to step up to the microphone and allow your inner American Idol to come out and SHINE!! KaRaOKE Baby!!! 

This is the place you come to if you want to get loud and have FUN! No reservations style!!

Mama Candy is a doll but if you get out of line she will put u in your place! She's always very welcoming to my friends and I and has offered us complimentary shots and has even offered us some of her chicken dinner before! LOL! 

The restroom scares me though...not because of sanitary reasons but because it reminds me of the bathroom scenes from those SAW  movies, where the person "wakes" up to discover one of their ankles chained to some pipes against the wall. LOL.
author: A C.

description: It has been a while since I have seen Mama Candy, but the times i have shared with her are crystal clear in my memory. From the gong she rings, to the shots she happily drinks along with her patrons, to the old, non-English speaking Chinese men who creepily stare at you.... Everything feels right here. I make a point to belt out a couple songs. The last time I was here, Mama Candy hooked it up!  I dunno how but I told her I was starving and the next minute, some Chinese guy delivered Chow Fun.  Mama Candy is the shizzzzz.
author: Gracie A.

description:
MAMA CANDY!

This might have been one of my favorite nights out in SF in recent memory.

Started out stopping here for a quick round of karaoke. I had no idea what I was getting myself into. 

From the pics and videos I have from this night, I had a bunch of shots with Mama Candy, the owner. Sang a lot of karaoke with some middle aged, shirtless, asian men, and just got flat out drunk. This place is awesome. 

Tucked away in Chinatown, the bar is narrow and packed. 

They have a pretty wide range of songs. This awesome hipster couple picked "It Wasn't Me" by Shaggy,  someone else picked "Santerria," and there was some N*Sync also.

I'd definitely start off a night here just to get drunk and sing before stumbling off to get your dance on elsewhere.
author: Karma B.

description: A true classic bar. Thank god we came here last night. The bar snacks are as shitty as you can find anywhere else my ex ordered a drink last night and it took over half an hour just to get to us. At this point nancy was about to explode. This is a place if you're looking for warm beer, cheap college specials, and loud tourists and entitled young rich kids that swarm from their tech companies in SOMA.
author: Benjamin L.

description: The most interesting karaoke bar I've been to in San Francisco. A mix of white and Asian people in a very small place but yet very accommodating.. Most songs available!!! Drinks are decently priced.!
author: Misbah A.

description:
I'm sorry, Bow Bow, that I haven't stopped by lately.

It's your new-found popularity. Remember the times we had, ages ago, when the bar stools were as empty as the street outside? Remember when Candy would offer buying a round and pour the cheapest thing in the house, and then dare someone to buy a round and pour something pricey (and herself two)? Remember how Folsom would fire up his karaoke machine and sing "The House of the Rising Sun" (the 1964 version) over and over? Remember all of the No Smoking signs plastered on the walls, and how the possibly-underage barback would chain smoke?

No, I don't imagine you do. Well, except the karaoke thing; it's all anyone ever says about you now.

I miss you. I miss what we had. But you have new friends now, and no doubt a new sense of purpose and the charisma that comes with it. That's good; you deserve it.

If that barback isn't underage, tell her to call me.
author: J. S.

description:
What happens at Bow Bow:
Make sure you're not wearing anything nice.  Shot of tequila please.  Points if you can order in Cantonese.  Sing Livin' on a prayer.  I'm All Out of Love.  Drink more.  Take iphone pics that don't need instagram cuz the red lighting is auto-instgramming the awesomeness.  Drink more. Use their HEINOUS HEINOUS GOD AWFUL Smells like the slush in the 2nd ring of hell bathroom.  Drink some Tsing Tao to sober up.  And do not go back until you're ready for some blackout action.
author: Jae H.

description:
I love this little bar in china town!  The bartenders are always friendly.  its kind of small so I don't usually stay too long but its a great place to stop in for a shot and a beer on your way to your final destination.
They also have Karaoke in the back and that's always good for a laugh...
author: Antoine V.

description: This place is a very small dive in Chinatown. Not too much to write about except the bartender is very nice and she was giving out free shots all night. I had a lot of fun and drank wayyy more than I should have. They also have a karaoke machine.
author: John D.

description:
I  #%$&-ing Love this place!!!...I don't even have the words to tell you how I feel about Bow Bow and how much I Love MOMMA CANDY. 

My brother and I actually call Momma Candy our "Mother from another" because she takes you in like family- and the way that this family gets closer is with Patron. Every time I come here she gives me the "special nuts" has my drink ready and my song qued up (now I sound like a total barfly) but she really knows how to make a girl feel special. 

This is a tiny hole in the wall, but comes with a level of charm that you wont find anywhere else in the city- plus for those who are brave, the audience for Karaoke is super supportive (and drunk).  One day Ill try my hand at one of those Cantonese songs that everyone seems to know the words to. $20 for two drinks- make sure you buy Momma a shot of Patron for me.
author: Sarah M.

description:
This place was a fascinating find thanks to Yelp!  After dinner in nearby North Beach, some friends and I wanted to sing.  

The bar is quite small and the place first appearted a bit sketchy.  When we finally asked about Karaoke, the lady at the bar directed us towards the end of the bar.  They have one microphone and a pretty decent song book selection. 

We were all having fun for a bit until the smoking started. Cigarrettes and weed. Yes, I typed that correctly. It was fascinating as there was a No Smoking sign on the front door and a funny complaint document taped to the nearby mirror for all things.. for not supplying ashtrays.  Random.

The place did perk up with more singing from more patrons, but I felt like I was suffocating because of the various smoking substances. 

Would I go here again?  If I wore a mask so I could breathe.
author: Theresa N.

description:
This place is a trip.  

I only wish I had been in town for more than one day or else I definitely would have tried to end up here at the end of the night.  From the four elderly men at the end of the bar throwing dice and slamming their wooden cups down so loudly it was frightening, to the middle aged woman belting out a song in Chinese at the other end of the bar (occasionally handing the mic off to her uninterested husband for their duet) with a very odd music video playing in the background, I could tell this place was awesome.  

This place is tiny, the bathroom is gross, but I can get over these things for great atmosphere, a good story and a place that is clearly loved by locals no matter what ethnicity.
author: Caroline B.

description: To me, this is what a karaoke bar should be.  Casual and fun!  Maybe even too casual for some.  Mama was so much fun.  But, I must never do Chinese whiskey shots again no matter what Mama says!
author: Adventures Of Harry S.

description:
I've never been to Bow Bow any earlier than past Midnight and I've never been to Bow Bow sober for that matter. As such, I've always attributed the good times to lots and lots of booze that results in rambunctious singing and biased mutual praise and encouragement.  

My last trip back however happened at around 8pm. While we already had a few drinks, we were by no means karaoke-ready. It did feel odd to enter the bar that sober. The clarity was disturbing - a sense of deja vu over some nasty deed. But we were singing in no time and all was forgotten. 

It ain't a classy place but it's endearing. From the interesting regulars to the fiesty owner/hostest, you're bound to interact with new folks here but at the end of the day, we're all here to have fun anyway. So pick a song and down that liquid courage.
author: Jon L.

description: Mama Candy is a rare gem.  My friends and I randomly chose to go to a karaoke spot and we were so happy we came here.  The best!
author: Natalie Z.

description:
Crazy angry Chinese bartenders/ owners.

Bad drunk karaoke singers. No oversight of playlist, meaning lots of repeats throughout the night.

Drink requirement to get to sing. Impossible to get the attention of the bartender and/or even make your way back to the karaoke TV it's so tiny and crowded.

Tacky Chinese decor + typical Chinese household snacks (sunflower seeds - my favorite brand! - & peanuts).

Crowded. And they propped the door open on a cold rainy night.

Fun times.. mostly because my friends were there.

Interesting place... but I don't think I'll come back.
author: Ziyan C.

description: LOL, a legendary karaoke spot in the heart of Chinatown. No other gem like this tropical drink specialty bar. A guaranteed unbelievable story every time!
author: casandra h.

description: A pretty good time. Run by a sweet lady who bartends by herself. Kareoke is a nice perk to this quaint dive bar, but don't ever select under the bridge. It's the weirdest kareoke rendition I've ever heard. Lucky is the Britney Spears version, not by Jason mean. Ask me how I know.
author: Yohan K.

description: Jameson is $7ish here, an important fact to know as you'll likely need to be soused to deal with the crooning at this joint. It's a fun place, no doubt, but karaoke, especially in a small venue like Bow Bow Cocktail Lounge, gets a tad intolerable after the second poorly sung Journey ballad. Hipsters aim for the $6 bottle of Tsing Tao, but as a smart boozer and connoisseur, you know that is not good biz for you.
author: Keane L.

description:
An Evening With Candy Wong
We started out our evening in North Beach San Fransisco with a visit to a great dive bar with a live band playing rockabilly blues. From what we hear this bar normally smells like puke or skunked beer but on our arrival, it was simply just poop. The music was good, the whiskey was cheap, and the fifty year old Swiss women had tongue rings. The place was festive and truly more fun then your average east coast dive bar unless you get the jukebox at the Silhouette. Once intoxicated on cheap Whiskey, we left to find a karaoke bar. What we found will be remembered forever.

If you've ever crossed into the San Fransico bay from near or far, you may feel a certain electric energy that could make or break an evening of irresponsible behavior. Candy Wong's has an out of nation feeling and definitely owns some of that electric energy.  We noticed this upon entry when we saw 30-40 Asian men chain smoking cigarettes and karaoke singing Cilene Deon and canto-pop. We were immediately asked to leave in Cantonese, but soon after were allowed to stay because we ordered Patron.

We thought we were entering just so we could smoke while we drank, and soon were in line to sing "Come to my window" and "November Rain".  As we watched each Canto-Pop song get sung, we made another friend and collectively think that by the point we were too far gone to remember we were indeed invited back. Candy Wong herself, the proprietor, once seeing the financial opportunities in our short stay, made us sing a song somewhere lost in the female singer songwriters of the 80s. We agreed, and sang to one more Patron and to be honest we forget the rest of the night.
author: Alex L.

description:
Bow Bow is definitely a dive bar you should check out!

Some friends and I made the trip to SF to participate in the St. Patty's Day festivities. Bow Bow was one of our last stops of a long day, which included drinking in the park and enjoying the beautiful weather, bar hopping downtown, eating in Little Italy, a roof top party... and I'm sure a few other things that I can't remember from drinking whiskey all day. Anyways, some friends of friends insisted that we go to Bow Bow for some drinks and karaoke. It's a chill, little dive bar. The drinks weren't as cheap as you might expect from a dive bar... Jameson was like $7. After a few songs, something went wrong with the microphone causing a lot of feedback from the speakers. We queued up "Sitting on the Dock of the Bay" by Otis Redding and spontaneously the whole bar began singing it aloud... I don't think I've ever heard a better collective rendition. Good times! I'd definitely go back again.
author: K Z.

description:
I Love Mama!!!

Ok, this is not your typical bar. This is a bar where you want to go sing your heart out with random karaoke songs and a place to listen to random old people sing! This location has a mixture of crowds. You have the typical bar hopping 20s, and you'll also have your chinese uncle in his 50s coming here. Expect nothing but a fun night where you can sing and dance with random strangers! The place is tiny, but it is pack with tons of fun!

Oh, and this was my only visit... I'm ready for more! Who's ready to do some karaoke!?!
author: Sappho C.

description:
1) worst bar I have ever been in 
    A) worst karaoke bar I have ever been in


Downright rude.  Complete jerks.  I have nothing good to say about this place.  They charge you $2.50 for a glass of tap water!!! TAP WATER.
author: douglas B.

description:
Rolled into this place completely by a random accident.  

They have a selection of Cantonese songs - how awesome!

It is an original - literally the gateway to Chinatown.
author: Kali F.

description: lost in translation, made up with panache.  walked in here with everyone singing country road.  people walking out smiling.  we knew we wanted to check it out.  casual vibe.  everyone wants to join and sing along.  owner bartender is great business lady.  nice and to the point.  when no one is singing, chinese karaoke is the default.  after all, you are in chinatown.  stiff drinks, good prices, and great vibes all around.
author: I Be E.

description: I've been here once and loved it. To sum it up, as long as you're drinking, Mama Candy is happy. And as long as Mama Candy is happy, you'll have a good time. :)
author: Jamie G.

description:
Oh man.

I don't even to where to begin with you, bow bow.

Reluctantly walking in at 7pm when there were only 2 people at the bar and asking "ummm....do you guys....have karaoke here" is definitely the best thing that happened to me that night.

The next 5 hours were a blur of fantastic + terrible singing, boatloads of whiskey + peanuts, chinese dice games, smoking, douchebags, slight gangstas, and a few hipsters thrown in for good measure. And of course Mama Candy, who did no fewer than 5 shots of patron topped with vodka. Hardcore.

Why their karaoke list has hurts so bad instead of hurts so good is beyond me, as is the fact that they list the artist for only about 10% of the songs. 

You better actually be able to sing, or at least not mind making a total jackass of yourself, cause the karaoke here keeps it real - it's unforgiving as hell, but that just makes it all the more entertaining ;)
author: Monica C.

description: Mama Candy is the best!  A few of us were first timers out of our group and as long as you are happy, she is happy.
author: Kimberly L.

description:
I'm giving this place 5stars because I always have fun here. The place is small and sometimes it may be hard to get the attention of the bartender when it's crowded. Drinks are huge and strong, the way I like it! Free Karaoke with one mic isn't too bad and they have a very extensive list of songs. 

Nuts with your drinks are available and if you don't want to sing, they have the good ol' Chinese Dice game of Bullshit available. 

I recommend trying the Chinese Whiskey LOL. I don't know any other place that serves it nor do I know where to get it. 

Everyone is friendly there and I LOVE MAMA CANDY! She is so awesome and very entertaining. I'm her favorite too ;) When we were there for the first time, she gave me and my friends nicknames. 

Despite the small bar and people smoking, I can still have a great time here with friends. It's a nice place to get away from all the fancy shmancy bars. =)
author: Jeffrey W.

description:
It's places like this that just make San Francisco.  The last time I was in here, I turn to my left I see three Chinese women speaking Mandarin (or was that Cantonese?), playing dice at the bar.  One actually lights up a cigarette!  I turn to my right, I see a group of Marina Bro's and Ho's singing karaoke while engaging in a mating dance that would make the birds of paradise jealous.

this place has more juxtaposition than a gay man teaching yoga in a christian church

and that's why we live here
author: Sameer D.

description:
What a funny little bar. I have taken note of this place for future gallivanting in North Beach and Chinatown. It is a great location. 

There is Karaoke offered in Chinese, Vietnamese, Hindi, Tagalog and Thai. As well as English and Japanese. 

Yeah I sang a bit. The bartender made my drink much stronger after the 1st song. I think she liked my voice.
author: Infodiva B.

description:
Right at the beginning of North Beach but still technically in Chinatown, this place is more reminiscent of a place used as a front for a smuggling outfit than a fully functioning bar. Rarely have I ever gone in and found more than 4 other customers. What they lack in decor and overall aura, they make up for in heavy pours and bar snacks. Last time we got pistachios, pretzels, peanuts, popcorn and tequilla!

The karaoke gets cranking here more often than not, so warm up those pipes and get ready for your best rendition of "light my fire"
author: Tony C.

description:
This really is a bar that happens to have karaoke. As opposed to a karaoke stage that happens to have a bar in it (e.g., Mint). You get the full mix of video accompaniment, from just plain text on a blue screen (newer songs), vintage music videos (mostly MTV hits of the 80s), and random montages of cultural ceremonies and scenic vistas of the world -- my personal favorite. 

Hospitality and ambiance are one of a kind. Mama and Jonny were serving last night, full of conversation, shots, and encouragement for shy singers. Almost no wait if you are courageous enough to put in a song request. This is not where hardcore karaoke ringers go since the selection and setup are pretty casual and the whole place is so small and cosy. The regulars, both Chinese and hipster are friendly and chatty. They know they found something special. Meeting friends here is almost like renting a large-ish room at a noraebang, but with a flow of friendly strangers in and out and great barkeep with drinks as soon and as often as you want, also parking everywhere as far as the eye can see!!! BOW BOW FTW.
author: Davie Y.

description:
I used to love coming here... we are pretty regular customers. It's such a fun little place with odd videos to go along with the songs (they don't even match the song... ie clowns running around on a boardwalk for "my way". haha) 

Came here last night with a group of friends. It was pretty empty before we got there so it seemed ok that we came in in one big group. The bartender was ignoring us pretty much the whole time and then we couldn't make a request for kareoke unless we bought a drink with it. "You buy a drink, you get a song."

There was another guy just sitting behind the bar doing nothing and wouldn't help anyone, just referred us to the bartender. 

Also, the drinks were suuuper overpriced on this night for a dive bar. A regular vodka soda with well vodka was $7. 

I even asked the bartender, after he continued to give us the cold shoulder and wouldn't help us, "Do you want us to leave or something?" "We can leave." 

Well, eventually we did leave. 

Usually when we come there is an amazing older asian man who is super friendly, dances with everyone and is the perfect employee for a kareoke bar! I miss that guy. 

I may consider coming back if that guy is ever there. But for the most part, I'll be taking my business to Encore up the hill.
author: Claire b.

description:
I am the mayor here. Don't even think about singing after me. I have the song numbers programmed in my IPhone.

You get nuts with your drinks. (Take that however you like)

The place is tiny, the songbook is like 10 years old. But we have fun, lots of fun.

Yes i admit this review is obnoxious. Sometimes I roll like that, especially after I STRAIGHT OWN Lionel Richie and Stevie Wonder. And don't forget about Usher, cause U Got It Bad!

This deserves a LOL.
author: Derrick V.

description: Two words: Mama Candy.
author: Fakename D.

description:
Booze? check (duh)
Karaoke? check
Bartender? Check... and she comes complete with an 80's style feathered out mullet. All she needs is a sequined shirt!
drunken yelpers? a work in process
Gong? Check.... Wait a flippin minute.. a GONG!?

Yeah that's right, this lady had a freaking GONG and she had no shame in making it go BONG!! BONG!! BONG!! each time a Yelper finished singing. Why? Because Yelpers scored 98 and 99's. Okay the machine is probably rigged somehow but 

BONG!!

BONG!!

BONG!!
author: Susy C.

description:
went in on sunday after the super bowl. like many other 49er fans in the city, my spirits were down. the sadness on my face must have been so apperant that the owner offered to buy me a drink. i ended up spending $49 in total, i tipped her $6. looked at my bank account, turns out she charged me an $80 extra on top of that. there is an $135 charge on my account. i have called and called and called. still not  unable to leave any messages or get in contact with anyone. if she sees this or anyone knows her, please have her contact me. my bank has said they have to investigate before returning me the $80 that she shouldn't have charged


other than that, i had a great time. but this has really left a sour taste in my mouth.

(i dont live in san francisco, in fact, had driven from los angeles to watch the game in the bay. i can't come back to the bar to ask her for a refund)
author: Jenny O.

description:
Went in here for an extended session on St. Patty's as literally every bar in North Beach, had a ridiculous line to get in- even Mr. Bings. At least this place, we were able to get a spot at the bar and watch some basketball. When we walked in, the bar was a disgusting mess- seemed like every used beverage container the bar owned was dirty and on top of the bar, along with pistachio shells everywhere. The female bartender I would guess could easily blow about a .18 as she went about her business. She had the reddest,  painfully dark red colored eyes as if she was just pepper sprayed.. Then the William Hung like karoake started up. There were a lot of wasted people in the place- it was St Pats after all....

The bartender did make a bet with us that if our team lost, she would buy us shots, and visa versa if our team one. Well, our team won, and we were out $29 bucks for shots, including her's. WTF? you are gonna charge $30 bucks for 4 shots in this shithole?

At the end of the day, you aren't gonna find a place like this in Fresno, or Lodi, or Phoenix... or Denver. There are only 2-3 cities in the country you will find a character filled place like this.
author: Jim B.

description:
I have to mentally prepare for this place, before I go.  For one thing, I know I will get absolutely trashed here, with Candy tending bar.  There's also something tweaky & fun-house-like about this wonderfully strange & friendly bar.  Candy is in charge here (Happy Happy!) and that's a good thing because she is a total pro.  It's worth going just to watch her in action.  Added bonuses will be all those things everyone else has mentioned.  My personal favorites: Candy the bartendress, Folsom singing "House of the Rising Sun," endless supplies of pistachios & peanuts, & the random crowd.
Candy is drinking Patron these days.
Buy her a shot.
Happy happy!!!
author: Ravena F.

description: I love this place, and they love me, riiiiigggghhhht. One of my favorite "end-ups" in Chinatown, on a weekend night. Mama Candy and Johnny run a tight ship, and you can always make a friend or sing a 70s favorite. Beware the Chinese whiskey.
author: Anna B.

description:
I've probably stumbled out of here dozens of times with a smile on my face while asking myself... man why did I drink that last tokyo tea?... hmm let's go get some Chinese food at Sun Hong Kong!

This is a bar with a ton of character and Candy is a staple of the area. Drop by, say hi, sing a few songs and have some fun. 

Little note: I think drink prices have inflated a lil over the years but its still fun.
author: Byron C.

description: I came in here last night after someone said "let's go karaoke!!!". a quick google search led us to this quaint dive bar. It smelled like China town and we knew we were in the right spot. We loved the hospitality of Mama Candy and divey atmosphere (cheap drinks to boot). When it was our turn to sing, we got the whole bar going and it felt like Choir. We didn't leave until well passed midnight...and it was pretty packed when we left. I love stumbling onto an unexpected gems like this in the city. We will definitely be back!!
author: Paulina T.

description:
Yes, it is a dive bar. And, yes, there is karaoke.

On the positives:
*Cheap drinks - I think my vodka soda was $5. What?
*No need to bribe the karaoke maestro (just wait in line!)
*A low key environment for karaoke...with plenty of drunk back-up. My friend really wanted to karaoke, and last time I was there, the other people in the bar were singing waaaaay louder than she was!

Negatives:
*Not very good translations on the karaoke TV...or in the karaoke song book (a bit to be expected)
*Small, narrow bar makes navigating tough
*Karaoke machine and TV is right by the bathroom. A bit awkweird...
author: Wendy L.

description:
I don't know why, but this place was awesomely weird for me. It's a freakin dive bar but all the bottled beers started at $4.50. Fine. One Coors Light it is. I was then asked if I wanted to sing a tune or two by the bartender that looks like he could be in a triad and these Chinese men around me. I'm no wuss when it comes to karaoke, so I chose an old school Chinese ballad and sat cramped in the corner looking high up on the wall where the TV was for the words. 

After singing my heart out, I went back to my seat at the bar. These young 30-something Chinese people sat next to me and started playing some dice game and smoking at the same time...indoors! I guess I should be lucky that we were seated near the door? 

During this entire time, Mama Candy was serving up drinks and speaking in a raspy high pitched voice. I can tell she's a cool cat, very nice and accommodating like a mama would be. It was quite an interesting experience.
author: Diana C.

description:
Bow Bow was another one of the dive bars we hit during the Yelp pubcrawl here I got to see/hear some SF Yelpers Karaoke. I've got to give it up to this place their karaoke selection is pretty good and the videos are cheesy and random just as they should be!

Oh, also major points for having snackies on the bar... snackies are always a plus no matter what Ben Stiller's character in Along Came Polly claims about germs!
author: Lori K.

description: Worst experience ever. 'Mama' drunk beyond belief and we come in with 7 people. Only about 5 other people there. We all order beers and on friend asks for water because he's not drinking. He asks for 2 refills and she yells at him saying she loses too much money to give him a glass of water. And... Her son tells us we can't do karaoke. Your welcome for the business. Sorry for asking for a water.
author: Melissa B.

description:
I didn't know what to expect from this little Karaoke Spot.  At first when I walked in with my cousins, I thought... "Oh my God!  Another small version of Cafe Moda!  How can anyone fit in here?  There's no room!"  But even though there's just a row for a bar, a small tv for karaoke, and limited bar stools the bartenders and wonderful hospitality completely changed my mind about this place.

The girl bartender, Candy, was just so super awesome with a bright smile, cheery personality and sweet persona she brings out to the bar.  She knew exactly what I liked and I love the fact she just took over my drink menu.  Not many people can pull that off with me.  If I want something I'll have it, but it was just different with her.

The highlight of the evening was being able to sing and just strut my talent for singing.  Mostly done in the shower.  :P  The song selections were immense and I was overwhelmed with making a decision for my first song.  But, with enough alcohol in my system, I was able to pick one.  But I had too much to drink and now I dont' remember what song I sang.

One of the drinks she made for me, which I am craving for right at this moment, is called a Bow Bow cocktail.  Mmm... it had the perfect blend of alcohol and juice.  I just don't know what's in it.  I guess it's her way of making me fly back to San Francisco to have some more.  I would go back over and over and over again if I was living there.  Come to think of it, maybe I should fly out there this weekend.  :)
author: Sarah N.

description: So we walked in with  a group of people and I ask Mama Candy what she recommends, she proceeds to yell at me for not knowing what I want and then mixing us up a line of kamakazes. Her attitude was pretty over the top, if only the drinks could have had the same kick.
author: Stephen S.

description:
This place is where awkward meets awesome. 

The crowd can either be pretty mellow, or pretty rowdy, depending on the kareoke machine's next play-- but everyone is looking to have a good time (including the overly friendly waitstaff who will gladly drink with you!) 

Don't expect a large space to sing / dance or anything fancy. What you come here for are the cheap drinks, free nuts, and the free kareoke (which you can practically dominate since the bar itself is small, there are relatively few patrons to compete with for stage time).

The only reason I'm docking a star from this place is because 1) the mike stopped working mid-song and the waitstaff didn't seem to care- it took a little while to get their attention about it and 2) all the songs are listed by name of song, not by band- which makes it hard to pick one after a few drinks.

Thank you bow bow for a great time. I will be back any time I feel like belting out in front of a small crowd.
author: Roxane W.

description:
All the stars were earned by Mama Candy. Probably a three star place without her. If you ask for a recommendation just nod and say yes. It'll be worth it. 

Not a good place for groups or karaoke. But what the hell, head in there with a bunch of friends and have a good time!
author: Michael C.

description:
Ten Reasons why I love the Bow Bow Cocktail Lounge:

1. mama candy's kamikaze with pineapple x 6
2. long island iced tea
3. (bad) karaoke
4. happy crowd
5. Free peanuts or pistachios
6. being handed a piece of salami from mama candy
7. (Really) bad karaoke
8. "hey baby you look good"
9. Cheesy backgrounds on karaoke screen
10. "hey baby if you buy me a shot I give you one for free"

good times.
author: Jeremy V.

description:
Easily one of the best little lounges on the Chinatown/Little Italy border area.

Folsom, the DJ/Emcee keeps the party bumpin' with the best Asian-ized hits for the karaoke crowd, while Candy the bartendress keeps the booze flowing. If you're really sweet (and willing to pay) she'll do a shot of Hennessey with you. Then, if you're even sweeter at the end of the night she'll produce a platter of hard boiled eggs and hot sauce for you to consume. Don't protest, it's rude. With any luck you will not remember the eggs until the next morning. Make sure that you're the first one to the bathroom for the fun surpise as the memories come rushing back!
author: Wes T.

description: the negative reviews on this are great... it's a dive bar, that sucks and punks everyone, and of course pisses in your face when you order water or sit there nursing a beer in a space better used by people who'd IV booze if they could.  Mama Candy hates you and your Abercrombie/Burberry/Dingleberry crowd whining about clean glasses and cash-only, but she pours you drinks because you're just dumb enough to get excited about nasty-packing yourselves in a shit-bar, so you can Instagram how last night you mixed it up in Chinatown with real Chinese people... it's like eating at KFC, and then complaining about fat.  enjoy the very low bar, or go to another bar.
author: King E.

description:
You need to come here in the right frame of mind. So my co-worker suggested we go sing karaoke and I was like " DONE". 10 of us went down on Friday night and we had so much fun. Not just with our group, but with random people there as well.

Mama Candy is like any Mama and I suspect if you get too rowdy, you get told to knock it off. The other guy bartender was a little cool with us, but got warmed up not too long after. Like any establishment, don't go in looking to make trouble, buy drinks, buy mama some drinks, sing awesomely bad karaoke and thank them when you leave. 

Awesome location. So close to everything yummy and well, N.Beach. It's really small so if you want to stretch out or not share the mic, then you'd better find an actual karaoke spot. This totally reminds me of home so for me Bow Bow gets 5 stars.
author: rei a.

description:
Comedy.com just ranked this as one of the 20 worst bars in the nation, but frankly, that is what makes it amazing.  The staff is a little odd, the karaoke is never of the highest caliber, the patrons are an odd bunch, and it's always blocking my path on the way home from North Beach.  

Mama Candy is sweet and always takes care of us with bowls of nuts and little shots of things she thinks are yummy, and you never have to worry about how you look, because everyone there is blind-drunk anyway.
author: Quinn S.

description:
This place is awesome. A must-do when all the other bars close and you're still hyped up to drink and be merry. The opinionated bartender who my friend likens to a "one legged prostitute" will serve you a hard boiled egg if you're lucky, and wet (boiled) peanuts if you roll up to the bar. Karaoke is the excuse to go, but getting this truly SF experience is why I keep going back. 

LOVE IT for drunken debauchery!
author: tania t.

description: The acoustics are not good here.  Drinks are reasonably priced.  I give a one star bc I was very disappointed w the hospitality.  We brought a group of about 40 here late last night bc of a birthday.  The place was fairly dead when we got there.  Bc the birthday celebrant's bday was on wed., however, (a few days later-obviously we preferred to celebrate w friends the weekend before) the owner changed her mind about comping a drink.  It wasn't a huge deal but it was just kinda rude; we didn't ask for a free drink.  She offered it, then asked for identification then said cahnged her mind.  Last time we have a huge gathering of friends at the bow wow.  And I really wanted to like this place.  :(
author: Jannah M.

description:
Bow Bow's has been the culmination of my bachelorette party, as well as my sister's.  Go here on Saturday nights after you've had your share of exotic entertainment on Broadway and belt out some tunes.  

The songbook may be a bit worn, but there are all the good classics in there - my personal karaoke favorite is Dust in the Wind, but was told by one of the regulars that it is too depressing for karaoke...whatever. (you're my boy, Blue!) .  Or, pull out a little CCR.  But please don't play Sweet Caroline twice in a row...really, that happened, and the guy sang it twice.

The hostess was super friendly on both occasions.  If I lived in SF, I would be a regular.
author: Christy M.

description: Awesome place! They, unlike many places in the city, make you feel like a Regular! We'll be back for sure!
author: Michelle G.

description:
DAMN my long island was strong... great bar tending at this place :D

Karaoke at it's finest - you choose and play your own songs, no tipping some DJ who will call you up to sing two hours later. Take your 4 tequila shots, work up you liquid courage and prepare to serenade the 3 other chinese patrons sitting at the bar.
author: Anne Marie S.

description:
Things that will most likely occur while visiting the Bow Bow:

Mama Candy will say:
Last one! Last one!
Don't get drunk, just get "high" (not in the illegal sense) or
He the man, he pay!

The entire bar will sing in unison to the karaoke songs, "Angel" by Shaggy and "Living on a Prayer" by Bon Jovi.

Mama Candy will show you her baseball bat from behind the bar

Folsom will tell you an awesome story about wanting to be in a motorcycle gang.

You will get drunk and have an awesome time!
author: Christina H.

description: When I went here,the woman at the bar refused to serve me for some resaon, the "karaoke" is actually a bunch of songs from earlier than 1990 and nobody can hear the microphone, and a fraudulent charge showed up on my friend's card for $100- she only bought two beers.
author: Alexandra B.

description:
I used to like this place when I was a smoker, but only during the weekdays.  It's chill on the weekday nights.  You can come in, smoke, drink a beer, and watch people play dice.

On the weekends, though, this bar is filled with the worst, most shameless Marina chodes ever.  Avoid.
author: Sasha S.

description: If someone punched a hole in a wall, put a bar, a karaoke machine and a guaranteed good time in it you'd have the Bow Bow Cocktail Lounge. Hands down my favorite bar in the bay area.
author: Josh H.

description:
I am in love. 

I am in love with the "karaoke" setup in this bar which consists of a microphone and plasma screen tucked in the corner of this skinny small space.

I am in love with the bartendress who locked the door to the bar and was selectively letting in only those she wanted to.

I am in love with the fact that the same bartendress was completely hammered by the end of the night.

I am in love with the fact that you will be yelled at if you are short fifty cents but will still get your drink.

I am in love with the people who actually applauded my singing here....oh, wait, I think they were applauding that it was finally over!!!
author: Drue C.

description:
Thick drink, smoking indoors (not my favorite part, but popular with all my "I only smoke when I drink" friends), free peanuts/pistachios.
