Mama is this crazy looking Chinese women who is constantly drunk but smiley regardless. Gave me extra pistachios in case I got too drunk. 

Favorite part: ghetto karaoke machine. Like any 80's Taiwanese import, the footage has nothing to do with the song/lyrics. Occasionally in between ordered songs I'd see songs my parents used to sing, in Mandarin. That's when I'd excitedly scream "holy shit I understand every single word!!"

Random Chinese people drinking shots and playing dice on the side. I consider that great scenery that comes with this divey gem.
author: Fiona S.

description:
Some bars are fancy and image conscious.  They're like the popular kids in high school who carefully mind what brands they wear.  They're professional and pleasant (to your face).  They carry fancy boutique vodkas.  They have drinks with names like "appletini".

Other bars really don't give a fuck.  They're the art kids hanging out behind the school smoking and drinking.  They'll tolerate your bullshit with a bit of a sneer.  Kinda.  Then again they might just lock the door on you.

Bow Bow is squarely situated in the second category.  You can sing karaoke, if one of the regulars isn't watching a samurai drama in Chinese.  Cindy might have had a couple of drinks before you get there.  Tipping is genuinely appreciated and may result in better service and possibly peanuts.
author: Christopher K.

description:
Last night a DJ saved my life!

Well, maybe just my job (which is not my life), but it was still a very nice thing to do.  The best part however, was that he didn't intend to save my job.  His intent, when he stopped playing our song requests and instead played songs that were clearly not karaoke, appeared to be to get my drunk ass friends and me to, at the very least, quit torturing everyone with our "singing", and quite possibly to get us to leave the bar.  Mission accomplished! Not only did we stop singing, we went home.  Woo-hoo!

Thus he saved my job --- instead of continuing to sing, drink, and smoke (WTF?!  I don't smoke!  I have asthma --- which means he DID save my life!) until closing time on a Wednesday night and be hung over and most likely late for the 9:30 a.m. meeting with my manager this morning, I went home around, uh, sometime earlier.  I got enough sleep & water to recover sufficiently to get to work early and finished the spreadsheet I needed to present to my manager at this 9:30 meeting.  

For that alone I would give 5 stars.  Additionally, unlike the Mint where karaoke appears to be an American Idol wannabe purgatory filled with aspiring Simon Cowells, the other bar patrons were quite, well, quiet.  Except when I told them to applaud the fact that I'd stopped singing.  Not applaud my singing (I was quite clear) but to applaud the fact that my singing had ceased and their ears, for the moment, were spared.  I would also give 5 stars for these gentlemen doing just that --- and doing it pretty exuberantly.

Minus one star for the lack of ABBA & Madonna songs (Take A Chance On Me and Like A Prayer --- that's it?  God help us all) and a list that is by song only (not by artist).
author: Alannah T.

description:
"Dive bar" has somehow become synonymous with slightly run-down or older joints that still serve top-shelf alcohol and have couture-clad clientele (500 Club *cough*). Maria D., Darla C., and laura b. are all REAL dive bar pros, so they may disagree with my assessment. But I would definitely place Bow Bows in the true old school dive bar category. 

I don't know why my dear friend Julianna loves this place and insists on going every Valentine's Day with a group of women to belt out "he did me wrong" love songs. The place smells of an unwashed frat house dance floor, rotten eggs, and throw up. The endearing alcoholic that runs the ancient karaoke machine, Fulton, works in exchange for drinks and enjoys singing The Doors songs every hour or so. The first time I saw him take the mic in his own hands and saw his song choice (Break on Through), I thought, "Oh dear Jesus, what kind of fool is this diminutive Asian guy going to make of himself?" And then out of this broken man's body comes a voice better than any LA cover band I had ever heard! The man can SING! 

The mistress of the bar just nods to the music and keeps Fulton liquored up, but gets suddenly snappy when people get up and suck. It is the one and only time I have ever been "gonged" and I can tell you that it is wildly humiliating to be out shined by a jim morrison-loving alkie who can barely stand. The proprietress also practically kicked me out when she realized that I was only drinking water (a rare detox phase I had a few years ago), even though I was tipping. 

So even though I'm not really popular at Bow Bow, it still holds a spot in my heart for, almost Tao-like, staying true to it's dive-y nature.
author: Gretchen T.

description: After enough drinks you'll be singing "Karma Chameleon"  by Boy George in a heavy and broken Chinese accent too.
author: Earl G.

description:
IT's A DIVE BAR! and what do most dive bars have in common, lots of weirdos.... but in our case, we had approximately 1. 

Guess who??? The bartender. all dress all slutty like.

Woman Bartender: "Hey baby.....how you doin?"
Stanley: I'm ok. 
Bartender: "Honey, what can I get ya?"
Stanley: I don't know. 
Susy: "What are you getting?"
Stanley:" I don't know, I'm thinking beer. What do you want Susy?"
"Hey bartender, I'll have a Fat Tire and a Citron Vodka with Cran for the lady"
Bartender: Anything you want honey, you want me to make your g.f. drunk?
Stanley looks confused: "She's not. and no, just make it good."

Ed walks in the door and everyones quiet. " HEY ED!" screamed everyone.  

Stanley yells :"Hey ED, I'm buying you two a drink!" CHEERS!

Outside:
Conversation with Keane, " You see any cute girls around?"
Keane: "No, do you?"
Stanley: Let's go somewhere, I'm tired of this place, the crazy bartender tried to hit on me."

That's all I remember! What a night....

ps. i REMEMBER ONE CUTE GIRL KATE K!
author: Stanley K.

description: I went there with some friends the drinks were ok but the customer that our regular only talk with each other. It a neighborhood bar
author: Travis S.

description:
I think that Bow Bow was the sleeper surprise of April's Pub Crawl (brilliantly organized as always by the lovely Drue C.)

 I cannot tell you how many times I've just passed by this bar on my way to somewhere else and thought, "Hey Self, we should stop in there sometime... Bow Bow looks pretty awesome."

My suspicions were confirmed about how awesome a joint this is... weird  karaoke with scoring... bartendress who is knee-walkin' - eyes crossed hammered by the end of the night and pours a mean vodka/cran... what's not to love?
author: Kate R.

description:
I inadvertently insulted the bartendress, Candy, by calling her a "hustler" on a rainy Saturday night. Ok, maybe it wasn't so "inadvertent'.  Anyway, my big mouth ruined what was probably the most enjoyable night of karaoke I've had in quite some time.

I walked in alone (because I'm a rebel) and immediately felt at home in this dive of dive bars. I sat with two gregarious asian dudes and a cook who offered to comp me any time I ever wanted to go to his San Leandro Chinese restaurant. It must have been my rendition of "Sister Golden Hair". It has hypnotic powers.

I will definitely come back here. If they let me in. 4 stars.
author: John T.

description:
I pretty much think this is the most fantastic bar ever. 

1) a awesome karaoke machine in the back 

2) the beautiful scenic movies that have nothing to do with the song you are singing on the karaoke machine that play along with the music 

3) A GONG! 

4) The bartender who gets HAMMERED right a long with you and yells at you in broken English 

5) The bar tender who YELLS at you in broken English about trying to trick her and continues to serve you free drinks

6) the hammer bartender who gave me a free bottle of water at the end of the night when I said I was done. 

7) The hammered bar tender that locked the bar door to keep people out after 2am but continued to serve the rowdy yelp pub crawl group. 

I think I might try and get the yelp crowd back here for my birthday next week... I LOVE LOVE LOVE Bow Bow
author: Jessica R.

description:
Hidden find for the folks who want something that is not average.  The ladies behind the counter were quick witted and slinging drinks left and right.  

This place draws all types and was unique enough that I would go back again.  Only part I do not like is the ability to smoke inside.  I am not a huge fan of that.  

The karaoke is so casual that I even gave singing a shot.  Who would have thought.....
author: Ryan B.

description: My cousins frequent this place for decently priced drinks and cheesy karaoke.  There's really not much to say.  If you want a dive bar, Bow Bow is your spot.
author: Paolo D.

description:
While the name is reminiscent of the Ferris Bueller's day off theme song, I wouldn't expect to find the elusive Chicagan here.

Long, thin, and reminiscent of a hallway, this lounge boasts a plasma screen and two powerful speakers as its karaoke system. Though the selection of Chinese and Thai songs are larger than the English selection (and about on par with the number of Tagalog choices) you're more likely than not going to be able to find something you'll be happy to sing.

Take a seat in one of the stools along the bar and grab a Tsingtao (as there is plenty of advertisement for it within the bar) and sing along. It's best o go with a group of friends, as this lounges small size can allow you to easily dominate it.
author: Keith M.

description: This place is very entertaining because of Candy! She knows how to charm her customers with free massages, and she can put them down with us too! Funny, nice and KAREOKE! is in the house!! She is smart feeding us those free nuts and giving us those BIG straws to drink with, I suck those drinks down like water, so bad on my wallet.
author: Karen T.

description:
I echo the majority of positive reviews.  

My bro has been coming here for about 5 years and it is seriously the most random bar one could choose.  It is one of those small, hole in the wall bars where the most out of mind stuff can happen.  Candy, or Mama as she said, is incredibly hard to understand.  I just shook my head and nodded with whatever she was saying.  She handed me some peanuts and a Miller so I could sober up.  

I'll be back for sure.
author: iPunchfish -.

description:
I love how Candy's hair is always perfectly teased and hair sprayed.  

Found the bow bow totally by accident a couple years back on our first ever Chinatown Bar Crawl on Lunar New Year.  I only frequent the bow bow every couple months or so because I always get way too drunk (or I'm way too drunk before I even get here) and embarrass myself singing Karaoke.  

Yeah I know, your thinking, "so what, that's what karaoke is all about."  Well, let me tell you something, when I'm at the bow bow I always think 'i know' a song pretty well and then know nothing but part of the bridge before the chorus.  Yeah, I don't even know the chorus.  Like 'La Bamba'.  I have these drunken illusions that just, you know, come over me.  So, most of the time when I mention that we perhaps stop by the bow bow I am almost always shut down by whomever I happen to be with.

I do enjoy when Folsom gets going on the karaoke.  If he's resistant to your pleas, just buy him a whiskey.  

Sometimes there are really obnoxious drunk people who will straight dominate on the karaoke..and sing Metallica.  It doesn't happen too often, but its been known to happen.

I like the video that accompanies the song selection.  Its like late 80s/early 90s, and its a mix of shots from famous landscapes (Eiffel Tower, Golden Gate Bridge) interspersed with little snippets of video of these like, Eastern European women.  Yeah its kind of strange.  I also enjoy how each song track is the like midi file of the original.  Like an electric keyboard.  You also have the option of singing your selection in English, Filipino, Mandarin, and Korean.

What also happens when I go there is that I order a beer and a whiskey.  Then, somehow, that same shot glass is in front of me all night, and I know I've been drinking them because I'm drunk, but the glass remains full.  When it's time to leave I am presented with a bill for $80.  Its this phantom pour thing, she gets me every time. 

But I must say, Candy takes care of ya.  After she's served you a couple she'll tell you, "Here, drink ice water first.  Then you have another one".  I appreciate that.
author: Emily X.

description:
A very late and drunken stumble in the door... and the best worst karaoke ever!  Behind the words, panoramic views of explosive volcanoes, wild horses, snow capped mountains.  It was so inspirational that I had to sing Hall and Oates' "Maneater."  

"oh oh here she comes
watch out boy, she'll chew you up
oh oh here she comes (here she comes!)
she's a maneater"

I got mad cheers up in here!  But I was sadly outdone by the karaoke master himself, when he followed up with "House of the Rising Sun."  My friends and I were practically ROLLING on the ground with laughter - just go on Saturday and you'll see what I mean.  You'll love it.
author: Jessica M.

description:
Unofficial private party bar. Special request Karaoke, the best background graphics of almost any karaoke machine.
The bartenders will put you to shame, after a few rounds, you think you're belting out the tunes top notch Whitney Houston on crack style and then the kar-tender comes along, and exclaims " this is how it should be done" and really belts out a tune in proper Frank Sinatra blue eyes fashion. 
It's small enough and large enough for anything and everything.
author: Mary Ella D.

description:
This bar is your typical hole-in-the-wall.  More aptly, it could be describe as a long alleyway between two walls where they put a bar.  There is more clearance between the end of my desk and the wall in my office than the end of the bar and the wall in the Bow-Bow, but that's part of the charm.  

Several things of note about the Bow-Bow:
1.  Beware of body odor.  The first time I came here, I thought I was going to puke - until I put back 5 or 6 drinks for 20 bucks.  Then it was fine.
2.  Beware of the creepy guy sitting at the bar next to the boiled nuts who just stares at you.  Or put back 5 or 6 drinks and you'll cease to notice the creepy stare.
3.  Beware the boiled nuts.  At first you think, ewww, boiled nuts.  Then you throw back 8 or 9 drinks and you think, YEAH!  BOILED NUTS!  
4.  Beware of the bartender.  After I had about a dozen drinks, I went to close out my tab, and the bartender was rather pleased with how many drinks I had purchased and then bought me another drink.  I clearly did not need another drink at this point.  

Best part, when I checked my credit card balance, my bill was only $85 even though I had purchased about 20 drinks (not all for me, just mostly for me).

Gas rating: 5
Okay, body odor counts as gas.  Even though it wasn't from me, the smell alone would have given this place a 5.  Add boiled nuts and it's all over.
author: Soo C.

description:
Karoake DJ,Folsom,  is no longer there, the smoke is out of control, and Candy depresses me now.
No more yanky my wanky. Bow Bow
author: HYnoon R.

description:
Wow... MAMA CANDY is Crazy!!! 

After bar hoping for a friends birthday, we ended here b/c he loves karaoke. I had read previous reviews about this bar, and all the things they said about it and Mama Candy & decided to take a chance. 

Man, this place rocks! Mama Candy is just as wild as everyone says. I was a little tipsy when we got in, after all the drinks Mama fed me, I was faded.  It was a great atmosphere, my buddy was loving the karaoke, and he got the whole bar to sing 2-3 of his songs with him. 

My only gripe about this place would be the smoking inside. Hence the 
4 stars.

Overall, if you don't mind the smoke, and are out to drink a lot and have a good time, then this is the place to go. Show Mama some love first, maybe even twice, and she'll definitely get you back.
author: Peter K.

description: i love mama candy, she hooks up the drinks and drinks over and over again.  always had fun every tuesday, friday and saturday that we frequent this spot.  karaoke selection could be updated but when you're with great friends having a great time, who cares.  definitely a regular here, not the mayor.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I love the old man with the tumor/lump on his head that runs the karaoke.

I love the bartender with the gun on her hip.

I love the owner who is as friendly and as accommodating as can be.

I love the pistachios/peanuts/cashews... NUTS.

I love this bar. I love that it is THE place to walk in and sing. It's the "no expectations" karaoke bar.

This is a no-frills bar, and if you walk in? Walk in with respect. It's not fancy, but if YOU are, you'll be finding your way out shortly.

Bow Bow? Gimme more.
author: kainoa r.

description:
Even if you're not drunk, you will feel like a drunkin' idiot at this very tiny dive bar.  If you're looking for a serious karaoke experience, this is not the place for you.  If you want to do karaoke at a place where you it will actually be your turn to sing in 2 minutes or less and you can care less about your singing abilities (or lack there of), this place is awesome.  They have a wide variety of songs in English, Spanish, Tagalog and HINDI!  But make sure you're not talking at the start your song or the owner will take the mic away from you and give it to someone more prepared to take on this serious karaoke challenge.

Mama Candy serves up some serious drinks and it seems like it is her mission to get everyone sh** faced.  You must get into conversation with her when you go...you will not regret it.  She's an eccentric Taiwanese woman who makes each and every one of her customers feel like they have been coming to this bar for years.  She's great!

I deducted a point for the amount of cigarette smoke surrounding that place.

P.S. If you're lucky, you can tap dance with the gentlemen at the corner of Broadway and Columbus.  He enjoys the company and you'll have a good workout.
author: Bharu J.

description: Very laid back but fun place to go after you want to get away from all the craziness at North Beach.  There is karaoke it you are into that, it's not a dead weird feeling of a lot of other karaoke bars, everyone usually is really bonding with each other the bar is so small, within a few minutes, it's like everyone is talking to everyone.  Candy is the owner and my aunt, she is very generous with her pours, she knows how to have a good time, and she makes sure everyone is too,  she is also sensitive to keeping an eye out for you if she thinks you  need a break.
author: Charla M.

description:
Candy calling me Honey all night = AWESOME. 

Requesting that Folsom sing House of the Rising Sun for the 10th time = AWESOME. 

Free peanuts = AWESOME. 

Buying shots for some bachelor party and Candy taking care of me when closing my tab = AWESOME. 

Drunken Karaoke = AWESOME. 

I think Bow Bow is Chinese for AWESOME!
author: Hector A.

description:
Screw this place.

I stopped in for a sec to see some friends before I hit the Hemlock for a show. I wasn't yet drinking that night. No big deal, right? Just being social.

My friends pressured me into singing a karaoke song. Why not? I picked the theme to the Love Boat. Great tune.

After scoring an 87 (not bad) and getting the crowd riled up (laughing at my cheesiness?) the owner confronts me:

"What are you doing?"

I told him I was just singing. He asked me where my drink was and I told him I wasn't drinking. He was pissed. I offered him two bucks or so for use of the singing machine but he scoffed at me.

"This is a business you know." He said and stomped off.

The female bartender (who had Tammy Faye Baker levels of makeup) approached me a few minutes later with a different approach. She smiled and asked me if I needed a drink. I said no. She asked if I needed a coke or a water. I replied no. She frowned and instructed me to smile more.

By that time I needed to go to catch the show so I left. My eight friends were drinking strong and spending plenty of money on drinks. It shouldn't have mattered if I was drinking or not.

Screw this place.
author: Tim K.

description:
Last night we rocked the socks off The Bow Bow Lounge. Now with a larger flat screen TV, The Bow Bow is probably the ideal place to practice your fav. Karaoke song. The English song choice is limited for this China Town dive...but when my friend's and I looked at the selection, it was hard to find a song we didn't know! From Wham! to Hank Williams...Aretha and (my favorite) Whitney...Bow Bow is an amateur singer's paradise. 

Some other reasons this is a beautiful gem of a find...

1 - If you are a smoker, feel free to light up right there in the bar...

2 - Never more than 2-3 people before you in line for karaoke -- most likely due to it being a week night that we went...but I've been there on the weekends and you still get to sing your heart out much sooner than if you went to The Mint or Encore.

3 - Mini bottles of wine. (supa fancy...ha ha)

4 - "cozy" and TINY environment that just doesn't put on any fancy clothes for it's customers...it is what it is and no one gives a crap. Being around those who don't give a crap is sometimes refreshing!
author: Katy A.

description:
bow bow is funny and very nice. gives you free shots and STIFF drinks. karaoke can get bossed up by one party but it's pretty easy to get your song in there. went on a saturday night, good amount of people, not too crowded. would definitely go again when i'm in a dive bar mood...

then after you can go find some snacks in north beach. perfect!
author: Kelly C.

description:
Quick, no nonsense bartenders when it was super jam packed here.  Throw up how many beers you want with your fingers here and mouth "Ka-row-na" and they will know what to do next.  5 seconds and you got your lime soaked beers ready lickity split.

I also really enjoyed pissing out my 5 bottles of beer here.  The door was so friggin close to the toilet that I grabbed the top and just hung on aiming for the bowl.  Picture Shaq's signature slam dunk pose.  That was me at Bow Bow's toilet.  Except I wasn't off the ground... that would have been awesome though!  Will attempt the Michael Jordan next.
author: Chris T.

description:
A fun dive bar in the North Beach area, where you can drink, sing and just hang out.  It's a small place - probably 25 people max. can fit in this place. If you like to karaoke - this is your place.  If you like to drink - well this is your place as well.

It seems that free beers or shot refills are on the menu -- especially when you think you are done. And... everyone knows Candy - the bartender.

Overall a dive bar to visit.
author: Sharon C.

description:
I love this place!!!!

If I said anymore I would have to kill you.
author: Tito C.

description: Candy wasn't around. Instead, there were three Asian men smoking like it was 1960 and a dizzy bartender. My eyes were watering and my throat was getting irritated, which killed my desire to karaoke. There's no other appeal and it's too small of a place to encourage you to linger. Moving on!
author: Kim K.

description:
Super fun place. The owner/bar tender was fantastic--the more she drinks with you, the harder it becomes to understand her, but I think that adds to the charm of the place. Coupled with the two dudes at the end of the bar SLAMMING dice, the karaoke machine, and the strip poker machine, this place is one happening joint!

-1 star because even after 5 rounds of drinks on an empty stomach, I was not staggering drunk.... hopefully that doesn't mean my tolerance has gone through the roof!?
author: K. C.

description:
I was LMAO reading all the reviews about this joint. ITS ALL SOOO TRUE lol!

I've had my share of dive bars, but this by far takes the top spot. Mama Candy never shuts up ... and I can't help but stare at her mangled teeth when drunk! She has a habit of conning your money too, but will give you loads of free shots to make up for it?

And yes, the atrocious singing was drowned out by the groupies of old, skeezy asian men in the front. And I was, too, had to keep ducking from the crazy drunk Burmese dude trying to cop a feel. And yes, I also loved how the karaoke machine "rated" every silly singer. 

But I loved how they let us do our thang. We got to reprise Total Eclipse of the Heart ... three times!

Had some good times, but it's not a place I'd frequent regularly.
author: Emily C.

description:
This place was terrifying. Don't get me wrong, I am all for seedy bars, but I have been spoiled by karaoke at the mint so I wasn't quite expecting the seedy creepiness of the bow bow (i could have sworn it was called "bow wow") when a friend recommended  we take our dinner party down the street to "a great karaoke bar."

The bartender was WASTED. And playing some kind of chinatown dice game with some of the patrons. I'm not sure what the game was, but the main point of it seemed to be slamming the dice cups as hard as possible down on the bar, evaluating the outcome, and drinking shots WITH EVERY ROLL. How this woman was standing, let alone serving drinks, is beyond me.

Then there was the crappy karaoke machine with the totally unrelated background movie of a young Asian woman doing Random Happy Shit. Twirling umbrellas in poppy fields, romping at the seashore, etc. while the engrish lyrics scroll across the screen. It also grades you on, apparently, your ability to shout read the lyrics exactly as they light up. I admit to not being the greatest singer but really? A 47? For Ray Charles? Not only does it grade you. It has some kind of evaluation along with it. Mine said "Carry On" - which I can only assume is some kind of polite translation of "Get moving! Next!" 

Then there were the old drunken men trying to grope any poor girl who started singing. My friend actually had to swat one away like a fly. Some industrious young man actually grabbed him and insisted that they gay slow dance together in order to get him out of my friends face while she did a "Pretty Good Singer (74)" version of The Rose. 

When I asked some lady about where the bathroom was I got this broken English reply: "It is through that door. Here is The Thing - do not be afraid. And return quickly."

Extra stars for the cheap booze and the amusing mis-translations in the song book. "Hindstone Cowboy" was my favorite.
author: Gabe S.

description:
Why I love this place:

1) Tequila shots with Mama Candy. 
2) Bad karoake background music makes my singing sound good in comparison.
3) Even worse background video makes my singing sound great in comparison.
4) The karaoke machine tells me I'm a "SUPERSTAR! 99".
5) Tequila shots with Mama Candy. (did I mention it was Patron?)
6) When I stumble my way through one of the 6 songs they have in Russian, no one knows that I've screwed up half the lyrics and instead, they give me compliments.
7) The little old men that dance with you.
8) A generally friendly crowd, even when a packed bar has to share the only 2 song books.
9) Tequila shots with Mama Candy.  (nuff said?)
author: Luba M.

description:
Great place to check out if you're looking for an interesting experience.

I randomly stumbled into this little gem and had the best time. Who knew getting drunk on Tsingtao and singing karaoke in a dive bar would be so fun?

The highlight of the night was trying to do Eye of the Tiger on their karaoke machine. The lyrics on the disc were so ridiculously wrong that I couldn't even "sing" because I was laughing so hard :D
author: Shawn S.

description:
This place has the biggest nuts I've ever seen. I'm not joking. I took one home in my pocket just to show it off. 

Pair the huge nuts with free  karaoke and a sweet comb-over - I think I'm in love.
author: Katelin H.

description:
The karaoke machine at this place is a little odd.  The lyrics are off, and so is the rhythm.  The videos seem to center on wildlife for no good reason.  And at the end of the song, you seem to get a score, although based on what is a mystery to everyone.

But its hard not to like this bar, with its odd mix of clientle and friendly atmosphere.  Plus, its close to a bunch of strip clubs, so its a great place to start the night when you are trying to get Monica L drunk.
author: Steve S.

description: I really wanted to check out this place - but had troubles locating it.... :(
author: Natasha S.

description:
It's somewhere between 3 and 4 stars, depending on how drunk you and/or the bartender are.

We went there last night for a bday party and the place is a hoot.  The bartender was completely wasted by the time we got there and progressively got worse as the night went on.  She was banging on her gong, throwing firecrackers out the front door (we thought we were victims of a drive by), mumbling incoherently as we tried to order drinks and then would charge us a different price every time or sometimes nothing at all.  

You'll love this place if you have a hankering for the weird and are not uptight about a shifty bartender.
author: Jen C.

description:
This is a fun karaoke bar to come to IF you are already drunk.  My girlfriend Sarah adores this bar, but usually comes drunk.  It is a small bar, so it can really get crowded.  What makes this bar special is Candy.
She is the Chinese lady bartender.  She has Lee press-ons, and serves peanuts on plastic plates.  Priceless.  However, she does make VERY weak drinks, so don't order mixed drinks.  Stick to beer.
author: Sarah F.

description:
This was my first time stepping into Bow Bow, but it will not be my last. I wasn't there for very long, but I can see how people would come here and never want to leave. The place is small so only bring your closest friends. There is multilingual karaoke in the back. Quite impressive. The bar keep is awesome. We had her version of the lemon drop. Yummy!

Oh and don't worry if you smoke...because everyone in the bar does too!
author: Andrew Y.

description: went there on a friday night with a huge group of people...service was horrible! Mama Candy was so hungry for money that she couldn't have been more obvious. our group bought tons of drinks but when several people in our group asked for water she got really upset and said that she can't give out free water ?! and the place is tiny and the songs are outdated. NEXT !
author: Kevin L.

description:
Love.  Love.  Love.

I love this place.  And it loves me.

I once ambled in of a Saturday evening (already five or six sheets to the wind, if you must know) to a packed house and was immediately handed a microphone and instructed to serve up my own deeply personal interpretation of Black Sabbath's 1971 offering, "War Pigs".  I did so and promptly brought down the house.

I also love the way Mama Candy will say as you're leaving, "Wait, I buy you drink," (at least I'm pretty sure that's what she says) and then charges you for the drink.

And of course I also love the way you can smoke pretty much whatever you want to.

If that ain't love, baby, I don't know what is.
author: Jimmy J.

description:
Once a month, me and some friends get together and bike around the city. To finish the exhausting day, we go to this incredible dive bar. 

As someone said before, it IS rather smoky in there but you don't worry about it too much as you are quite entertained with Candy, the bar's owner. She is super sweet and will make sure you stumble out. If your in Chinatown or near the Columbus/Broadway area and want a really chill spot with old school DeBarge playing, go see Ms. Candy and have some drinks!

P.S-That Chinese Whiskey is the BOOOMB!! ;D
author: Angela H.

description:
I try to get excited about this place, I really do.  I end up here due to some friend who absolutely love it.  It's got it's appeal, but I can never quite get fully behind the decision to go there.  

"Candy", the aging bartender/temptress with consistently plunging necklines, and Folsom, the crooner-cum-security who will belt out Ruby Tuesday as quickly as he'll get into an extended conversation about his pistol collection, set the wacky scene at this mix of Chinatown and North Beach.   The crowd is mostly frat-ty spillover from North Beach, with some other odd characters thrown in.  All vie-ing to try out the underwhelming karaoke set-up while ignoring the SF no-smoking regulations.

Cheap drinks, free peanuts, and worth doing occasionally.
author: Jason C.

description:
Now I normally refuse to give divey bars or karaoke the time of day, however after being given a run down of what to expect at a place like Bow Bow, I couldn't resist making an exception for just one night.

Bow Bow is definitely not about beautiful ambiance, but about the lovely bartender (or bartendress as you all refer to her as), Mama San. She is absolutely hilarious! Mama San served us our Tsing Taos and concoted some fruit punch-like cocktails and when we asked what the total was, she just told us to buy her tequila shots! So, she got stinkin' drunk w/ us while chatting all of us up- telling me how she'd find me a boyfriend, telling us all how beautiful her kids are, telling us how beautiful we were, telling us beautiful this and beautiful that.. (i think she just likes saying the word "beautiful"?). While chatting away, she ends up knocking one of the cocktail glasses to the ground behind the bar (breaking it), and then shrugs it off, leaving it in its pile on the ground while telling us that it's no big deal since it's her bar. Nice!!

The most entertaining part of this all was trying to figure out what she was saying. Apparently my friend (who's a regular) told me the secret to figuring out her dialogue, is to first understand that she talks like Cartman from Southpark. Once you get that down, you'll start to at least get the gist of what she's saying. She's also got incredible hearing... she can be all the way at the other end of the bar w/ karaoke in the background, yet still manages to hear you casually mention to your buddy that you're ready for another beer.

As far as everything else goes, the place is the smallest bar I've ever been to, with a flat screen in the very back and patrons belting out karaoke tunes at the t.v. It's not the cleanest, w/ peanut, pistachio & sunflower seeds scattered on the floor, along with the fact that they allow smoking inside, but given that it's a dive bar, it's pretty much what I expected.

So swing by and sing a couple songs & take a few shots w/ good ol' Mama San!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
oh bow bow~ how you don't disappoint. 
stumbled upon this gem after yelping "karaoke bar", and it just felt like home! 

not only were we greeted with chinese decorations, cheap drinks, and karaoke,  we were also WARLMLY welcomed by mama candy, who made us feel just like family. after she found out it was my birthday, she gave us some complimentary birthday parton shots, and we all "GAN BEI" with the the rest of the staff. it was definitely a great experience. 

mama candy, see you soon!
author: M Y.

description:
I have gone here for my birthday year after year and I have always had the most amazing time here.  The atmosphere, the drinks (I love it when you go to order a vodka tonic and Candy says, "No you don't.  I know exactly what you want." And then it comes out flaming and somehow it is exactly what you want...) Folsom is great, you can even get Budweiser ice cream next door.  Perfect. Right??

This year there was an article written in the Guardian or SF Weekly about how this is one of the best hidden spots in the city.  The past many times I have gone, it has been over-run with yuppy asshole Marina folks that have taken over the bar and turned it into a horrible experience.  This year on my birthday, I had to leave after singing one song because I just couldn't take the 25 year old Marina b-day party.  They sabotaged every song my group picked out, took the mike, punched in numbers so they came out in Cantonese.... just total assholes.

It is just so sad when you experienced how great a place was and then once again, the Marina takes over and ruins it.  Sorry to Candy and Folsom for the two stars... it is not you but the annoying invasion that has soured a hidden gem.
author: Carley A.

description: Well..there's not much to say. Positives - They have cheap drinks and karaoking..5 stars. Negatives - the place is cramped, tiny and ugly and the bartender creeps me out..1 star. While I think the positives outweigh the negatives be prepared to punish your senses before going in.
author: Shreya C.

description:
A few things to add about this venerable, dingy spot located conveniently in otherwise Bar-Hades (i.e. North Beach)...

1)  The Karoake dude has a penchant to snort cigarette smoke... it's true!  He'll tap you on the shoulder surreptitiously---like he's about to unveil his kidde porn collection---and then he quickly takes a cigarette, holds it to his nostril, inhales, and then blows smoke out of his mouth.  That's worth something... just don't know what.

2) This place draws a varied, random assortment of folks.  Two nights ago, a middle aged man insisted on singing "My Funny Valentine."  But when the music came on, he just stood there, looking blankly, as the ring-tone style music played on and on.  He turned to aforementioned karoake dude and pleaded that this was the "wrong version" of the song.  So, another version of the song came on and ... he stared blankly at the screen again.  The best thing was, that besides my booing, no one seemed to notice or care.

3) I diagree that this dive bar is "cheap."  I think Bud Lites are $3.50, which is not outrageous, but not great either.  In fact, this bar falls into my category of dive bars with un-dive bar prices.  (Mr. Bings, High Tide)
author: Paul K.

description:
So I was pushed into this place after my husband told me how hilarious it was and that we HAD to go check it out! It was already pretty late...about 12:30am or so and so of course the mostly college age crowd was WASTED beyond belief! Good times! 

The owners are the funniest part of the whole scene and I totally thought that at any moment I would hear a director say "CUT!". They were like something out of a funny movie. But I think I'm in love with the combover on the karaoke guy (and owner)....beautiful! 

So the singing was of course absolutely horrible by all that got up. So being that I was not drunk (i'm currently 5 months preggers) I knew that I should get up and do a little "Hit Me With Your Best Shot" because it probably wouldn't come out too bad since I hadn't been drinking. Well that might have been a mistake because after I was done this MUCH older Chinese man who had been sitting at the bar WOULD NOT LEAVE ME ALONE! LOL! I was sitting right next to my husband, but this guy came up and told me in VERY broken English how he loved my voice and that he was in love with me and then proceeded to kiss and hold my hand. FUNNINESS! 

So there you go...Bow Bow in a nutshell... make sure you are drunk, that you don't mind cigarette smoke, and that you don't expect the singing to be good...at all!
author: Shelly V.

description: Okay, I actually find this place quite a bit pricier than the other dive bars that I frequent, but Mama Candy is well worth it.  This place is TINY.. it's essentially hallway sizes, so not so great for socializing, but always an awesome time!  If you treat her right, then Mama Candy will start discounting, if not, give you your drinks for free.  Good times!
author: ThirtyTwo P.

description:
I had an awesome time at Bow Bow last weekend.  I had my doubts when I walked it, but Mama Candy made us feel right at home.  Pretty diverse crowd.  Miron (a regular middle-aged regular) would sing his Chinese ballads in between our Karaoke songs.

Mama Candy is fun.  She gave us free shots.  8)
author: Iheartcamels Y.

description:
Reading Yelp reviews on the way over, I was looking forward to running into Candy again. Just my luck, that she was off last night, and the place was dead. Jenny was the bartender (who I met years ago), but she always seems to feel more comfortable with Chinese customers. I had some very cold tsingtaos (which I hadn't had in a very long time), and snacked on salted peanuts in the shell. 

The nights entertainment featured a C-drama on channel 26. Two other customers were in the place. One of them was playing the tabletop touch  screen game, and was getting angry when the cards were not turning up his way. The other smiled at me and shook my hand as I left.

I will try to swing by when Candy is there, because I know from experience that she makes the place go. That review will follow up.

Bonus: the bathroom didn't wreak at that time, like it did in years past.
author: Mike T.

description:
you really have to know your song here - the words are off both in content and in the timing so you can't rely on the prompts to get you through.  The music is also not the actual track but some kinda casio keyboard rendition - real old school Karaoke.  

The mic is kinda brutal - you really need to be able to sing here as the synthed-music tracks are not good cover if you're an amateur like me.  But honestly - nobody gives a crap how you sound here, its great.

the guy managing the Karaoke is awesome buy him drinks he's good people one of those unique characters you meet in life that you'll never forget, great fun to talk to

the crowd was awesome - hot girls everywhere and no shortage of people willing to back up vocal through the tough spots.  I got drunk with the karaoke master, got some really deep advice on girls and dating from a complete stranger, met a (self proclaimed) mobster, and had one guy ask me why I didn't want his wife. good times good times :D

despite getting the shake down from 2 dicey gentleman and one dude trying to kiss me this place was the most fun i'll NEVER have solo again.  I mean, I had a kick ass time but when I left i was glad that I (1) i still had my wallet, (2) was still in one piece, and (3) was not being hauled off in a paddy wagon :P

I left with the odd feeling I had just lived some mashup of the movies Barfly, Goodfellas, and Duets

it was a late wed night, totally dicey, totally divey, not sure I'm heading back there anytime soon but wouldn't have missed that night for anything.
author: adam b.

description:
This is a good place to go when you want to get very, very, very, very drunk. But a bad place to go when you want to impress the cute new boy at your office. Case in point. There is a cute boy who started working in my office 6 months ago. Let's call him "Mario." Anyway, Mario is dreamy. And I wanted to make him into my dreamy, dreamy boyfriend instead of just the boy who I made goo-goo eyes at next to the express-o maker (that's right! we have something called an express-o maker. you just push the button corresponding with the coffee drink of your choice....it's pretty much the greatest invention ever made). So one Friday afternoon, I asked him what he was up to for the weekend. He said, "what are you up to?" I said, "I asked you first," and he said, "I asked you second," and I said, "I'm doing whatever you're doing," and he said, "I'm doing whatever you're doing..." so I said, I'm getting drunk and doing karaoke in China town. He said, "me too," I said, "care to do it together?" he said, "no, I just like to watch," I said, "I like to be watched." So we met up at Bow-Bow. 
Six very cheap vodka tonics and four rounds of Britney Spears later, we were rolling around my bed. At least that's what I thought. I was actually rolling around by myself on grant street. He was watching and trying to coax me into a cab. 
Me and Mario haven't spoken since. I think he's dating Angela from accounting.
author: Ahnui Y.

description: I'm not sure if it was the crowd of yelpers, the drinking, or the cheesy karaoke machine that actually rates you (because we all need a machine being critical of how well we can pretend to be Axl Rose), but this place left me with a distinct impression... of awesome.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Rewind to March 25, I had just spent five hours on the road, relocating from "The OC" to San Fran (DON'T CALL IT THAT!!!  I've been warned).  I was a bit nervous about the new city and only knowing two or three people, all who -  don't drink, don't smoke, don't curse and don't tend to stay awake past 9:30 on the weekend, 8:30 on a school night.  Needless to say, I get a random phone call from one of my Vegas friends letting me know "dude I'm in fucking town, it's time to party!!"  I'm still nervous, but hey, "let's fucking do it dude!!"  I get suited up and it's time to get loose!  I meet up with him and two of his friends from the yay area and it's on!  Bar after bar, drink after drink, finally at about 12:30, "Dude we're fucking going to Bow Bow's!!"
At this point, I'm drunk, I'm game and once again yeah, "let's fucking do it!"
I have no idea where the hell we are, we're walking through some alley and then I see lights, and then an abrupt left turn into what seems like your typical "row" bar.  After the initial "where the hell are we" wears off, my ears are greeted with the most beautiful sound....."Don chew wan me bay bay, Don chew wan me oooh oh oh oh!"  I look up and in front of me, holding a microphone, and reading the words off of a screen, with what appears to be a program from the 700 club playing in the background, is every kung fu theatres dream of man.  I call him BowBow, I think his name is Ted or something but for me, he will always be BowBow.  He was WASTED!!  I think to myself "this is my kind of a bar".  Just when I didn't think it could get any better, I hear "Jamie, meet Candy!"  Oh my eyes, the beauty, no one is going to believe me!  She  proceeds to pour us drink after drink and then it happens!!  Drum Roll...............She pulls out a plate and plops four hard boiled eggs on it, with some chile sauce.  "You eat, is goooood!"  Holy shit!  I don't know who thought eggs and alcohol go well together, but they don't.  We all took a deep breath and swallowed them down.  My friend being the classy guy he is "Dude that was fucking nasty, I'm going to have to take the biggest shit!"

Woooooooooooooooooooooooowwwwwwwwwww!

I decide at that point, I'm done.  I left my friends at the bar and stumbled around the streets until I found a cab.  And off I went, left with the memories of one of the best times I'd had in a long time!

I've only been back to Bow Bow's once since then and once again it didn't dissappoint.  The song book is still horrible, the sound is still horrible, it still has a weird smell, BowBow is still drunk, and Candy is still trying to get you to eat odd things at 1:30 in the morning!  

Bow Bow's you have won my heart!  See you in another three months, don't change a thing!!
author: Jamie B.

description:
everyone's definition of a dive bar is different. i've been amazed in the past at the kind of places that some people consider to be dives. well, when it comes to the Bow Bow, i'm sure everyone could come to an agreement that it's one of the diviest places around. the place is dirty and hazy from all the smoking going on inside it. peanut shells are scattered over the floor from the free peanuts served on the bar (watch out for the funky boiled ones, yuck!). at the far side of the room, people are screaming karaoke at the top of their lungs. man, even 5 drinks later, that karaoke still sounded horrific.

the patrons here we serious drunks. there was the drunk woman at the bar who stood up of her stool and then just crumpled onto the floor... she had to be helped up by the bartender, and then just sat their passed out till someone came in the bar, and carried her out. two wasted guys at the bar sat there and heckled everyone who passed by at the top of their lungs until they were threatened to be killed by a passerby. there was the vagrant who came in to demand money from the bartender. and of course, there were two guys who were obssesed with trying to get everyone to do karaoke and they called tom "cupcake".

so, yeah, this place was quite an experience. we all loved it and definitely want to go back. never a dull moment in that place. the bartender "Candy" was super friendly and kept pushing more and more beers on us. then, when tom asked for a free one, she just said "sure" and gave him a free beer. free beer?! yes, that's right.. free beer... truly amazing.

(my resolution this year is to visit 50 new bars in SF.  read about it at: http://fiftybars.thisisvlad.com)
author: vlad k.

description:
Bow Bow Special for You Hunny

This place used to be epic back when it would just be Candy. Although I still recommend it for the weekdays, the weekends are terrible it is packed with the trashy Broadway bridge and tunnel crowd and the place looses its bizarre Chinatown dive luster. 

RIP Folsom
author: S. O.

description:
you haven't lived until you've heard a fifty-year-old chinese gentleman with a drinking problem and a combover sing "house of the rising sun".

don't worry if you miss it. he sings it seven times a night.
author: Steve T.

description: This is the bar that always seems like a good idea at 1am...and it is.  Nestled in Chinatown, just behind Vesuvio, sits this tiny bar that looks inside like the Regal Beagle gone bad.  You can hear Fuson's rousing karaoke rendition of "House of the Rising Sun" several times while being served warm shots of free jaegermeister by Candy the bartender.  Dubious mixtures of nuts and chips are there for snacking, and the best part is...you can smoke inside.  Truly a hidden gem of a bar.
author: Lauren S.

description: "I Love You Mama Candy," that is what me and my friends yelled out as we walked/stumbled out of her bar on Saturday. The trick here is to get Mama Candy to yell,  "I like you-you good people" and the drinks keep on coming. Buy her a shot or two and you are good to go for the evening-she will get you back with shots and drinks. After a drink or a few I highly suggest jumping up and doing Karaoke: English and Chinese are your options-its good time. This place is an action packed lil' whole in the wall bar. Loves' it!
author: Aurora B.

description: This place is really really fun!  This is the kinda place that you can pack a big group of your friends into and have a great time.  Momma is a great bartender - she'll definitely take good care of you!  The selection of karaoke songs is limited, but at least there's nooooo line to sing (the place is too small to make for a big line).  This is definitely a place where you'd want to bring your own crew to.  We did my birthday here last weekend and Momma made sure to keep me rolling in the Patron, and we were singing all night long.  Definitely a blast!
author: richard d.

description: Great little bar complete with some interesting Karaoke. My friend sang about 4 songs and blew the place away. So much so, that the  owner/Karaokemaster sang the background vocals for "Easy" right alongside my friend and continued on the next song...
author: Nicolas H.

description: stumbled upon this divey bar this past weekend while celebrating my cousin's birthday.  the place is a small long narrow bar with a karaoke tv in the back and many drunken wanna-be-singers blaring away.  the place is dark and decorated with the typical chinese new year decorations and christmas lights.  what makes this place fun is mama candy.  it's kind of hard to understand what she's saying half the time - not sure if it's because she has an accent, drunk or both - but you definitely know what she's saying when she pores you a shot and asks you to drink with her!  she also served up some peanuts which was nice.  this is one of those fun, random night type of places.  don't come here expecting your own karaoke room or speedy bartenders.  do come here if you want to have an interesting fun night with mama candy.
author: Vic S.

description: Love this place! It's like eight feet wide and maybe 80 feet deep and it is filled with awesomeness. Wandered in here after dinner with some friends who wanted to get some scotch and sing some 80s power ballads (I mean, when do you NOT want to do that?) This is a total dive bar with one janky karaoke system in the back and really what more do you need in life. My friends and I got down to business singing Peter Cetera, Heart, En Vogue and some Carpenters for good measure. We thought we were doing pretty well and then crazy bartendress lady picked up the mic and busted out like she was Chinese Celine Dion. Girl can sing! My new favorite Chinatown dive bar.
author: Cathy T.

description: One goes to the Bow Bow for 3 reasons.  To smoke, to hear horrificly bad karaoke (is there good karaoke) and to get F*CKED UP! yes it's in all caps for a reson.
author: Jay W.

description:
Mr. Comb-Over the Karaoke DJ can be a little touchy, but man can he belt it out.  Like Don Ho except emaciated and smoking like a chimney.  This place is not lacking in characters.   A married friend kept being approached by a strange woman calling her "pretty girl" and imploring her to meet her shy friend.  For you single ladies out there, this is the spot.  
Cheap drinks, free peanuts, and the chance to really act like an idiot.  I'll be back to this place.
author: Robert H.

description: I have always had a good time at Bow Bow, even the time Candy the bar tender locked us inside to avoid a gang fight. Take a group of friends and take over. Candy and Folsom are quite a team. Candy is the bartender and Folsom is the Karaoke DC. Candy serves up cheap drinks and peanuts and you havn't lived until you've heard Folsom sign "Ruby Tuesday".  This is a great place on a late weeknight because you can bring the party.  Don't mind the old, quiet gambling Chinese guys at the bar, the'll be cool with you if you bring in drunk girls or they'll just take off if you get too loud.  Check this place out sometime.
author: Brian B.

description: Oh this place is the balls.  I went in here one time when I was really depressed and broke and the lady there kept making me eat these salty peanuts and singing songs to me and bringing me way too many bottles of beer... and than there was this cute asian girl who I think was her daughter singing karoake in the corner and dancing...this place rules
author: Francis K.

description:
stumbled into this place 4 years ago after getting kicked out of jazz at pearls for talking to the drummer.

don't let the old men smoking at the bar fool you...ask folsom for karaoke and wait until he finishes singing "house of the rising sun" and the place is yours...litterally.  by the time he is done, the old asain men have pretty much left, except for the one at the bar who cant keep his eyes open.

grab the big book of english songs and try to find more then 10 you recognize...the randomist book of songs i've ever seen.

thank you pearl for giving me this treat....way more entertaining.
author: kevin p.

description: What it is with me and dive bars these days?  Maybe it's the economy.  They say as times get harder, people look for increasingly inexpensive ways to entertain themselves.  Well, if you want to go someplace unpretentious, to have a few drinks with your friends and get up on the mic and sing really bad karaoke then this tiny, smoke-filled room, just off Broadway in Chinatown is what you're looking for.  The hostess, Candy, is fun and engaging, and she'll even slam a drink or two with you, if she likes your style.  Quaff your beverages and munch on copious salty snacks while you wait your chance at karaoke stardom.  And no one will mind when you butcher one of your favorite songs.  It's good, cheap fun.
author: Law G.

description: Bar maiden Cindy kicks ass! Great vibe and location! Just when we were ready to leave...we got free shots and the karaoke going.
author: Maureen O.

description: this is a very clean and small bar. i've known the people here for years. the locals  here have a lot of fun. can't see outsiders fitting it except to buy candy, the owner, drinks.
author: Victor G.

description: Booze, Ciggies, Candy and Folsom keeping everything in check.  The potential for the hard boiled egg gift from Candy, all the while making sure you've got a fresh bevy.  Total mix of patrons.  You GOTTA love this place!
author: david s.

description: THE best dive bar in north beach! Candy and Folsom are awesome! Try the lemon drop if you dare! Oh and did I mention free karoke? Ear plugs not provided.
author: Will M.

description: Mama Candy is the fucking best.  She is out of control and I love it.  I also love singing Steve Nicks and Neil Diamond.  I have definitely been in there past closing taking shots with Mama.  Epic.
author: Katie M.

description: Candy and Folsom are two of the finest.  Candy will definitely make you happy happy.  She has the uncanniest knack for sensing right when you're about to leave and giving you a free beer.  Next thing you know...it's 2:15am and you're still there...
author: Kerry L.

description: This place is bizarre in the best way possible.  It's dim, smoky, and the crowd's usually composed of a motley crew of older Chinese folks, people who clamor to get bar fame from singing some serious karaoke, and general weirdos.  But somehow, everyone seems to have fun.  Maybe it's because the drinks are so strong.
author: Helen C.

description:
One of my favorite spots to belt out a mean rendition of G'N'R's "Paradise City".  The bartender is fantastic --she told us exactly where to sit, what to drink (beer) and was quick with an ashtray and a light.
It's a tiny bar --so no matter where you sit --you're singing along.  Tons of fun --can't wait to go with a group.
author: Amy C.

description: This is a fun little place and one of the few karaoke bars I actually enjoy.  The owner/bartender is great and the crowd is there to drink rather than be professional singers which is fine by me.  Definitely worth a stop if you're out in Chinatown.
author: Zach J.

description: I had the time of my life at this bar. I thought I was the biggest star that night. Thanks, Bow Bow.
author: Brittany L.

description:
Do you like cheap drinks?  Do you like friendly bartenders?  Do you like to play dice?  Do you like to eat peanuts?  Do you like to smoke cigarettes indoors?  Do you like homegrown karaoke?  

If you answered yes to all of these questions, go to Bow Bow.  I love the place because it's small, friendly, and sketchy,
author: Shalom G.

description: This place rocks!  I ended up inside after just walking by and giving it a shot.  The bartender Candy is great; I'm sure how many free shots or beers went my way but they have no problem giving a free drink now and then.  They asked if I wanted peanuts and brought out these trays of dry-roasted and boiled peanuts, all unshelled.  Being from the american southeast I have a special place in my heart for boiled peanuts and ate them somewhat greedily after my 3rd shot of jameson's. My crew and I had the intention of bar hopping last night but we never left the "the bow bow". Oh yeah, and you can smoke cigerettes inside.
author: Jeremy P.

description:
You can smoke inside here.  The bartender, Candy, plies you with pistachios, peanuts, and cashews, and pours each of your drinks "extra strong, just for you."  Climate control is a dusty fan in the back corner; most girls who walk into the single unisex bathroom back out five seconds later with a look of horror on their face---and smack in to the cluster of so-loud-as-to-make-up-for-their-inability-to-sing-in-tune karaoke-ers who make the Bow Bow a regular stop on their way home from North Beach high jinks.

It's all kind of fun.
author: Hannah J.

description: Ah, Bow Bow.  Site of Colleen's debut karaoke performance, and SF will never be the same.  Not only did the owners put up with us, they sang at our request.  And man, you're missing out if you haven't heard them-- amazing!  It was almost enough to make us slink away with our tails between our legs.  Almost-- were it not for those 4-5 beers we each tossed back.  No, there was no shame to be had, just tons of fun.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Sheila W.

description: I have been there 4 times and that Asian guy with the glasses is always there singing that same love song on the karaoke machine...and my buddy is has some strange fetish with that bartender Sandy......I can't even understand what the fucks she saying.....But I keep coming back....but I am a odd guy to begin with!
author: tom h.

description:
This place is the best!!

Pros: you can get wasted for about 25 bucks!  The owner is the greatest.  

Cons: American Idol Wannabe torture & some smoking.
author: Dale G.

description:
Everyone seems to know the bartender/owner, Candy, by name.  With her teased hair and her periodic retreats to the restroom to spray away the scent, she's hard to forget.  As stated in these reviews, her drinks are weak, stick to beer.

Most of the night there was a man holding a life-size cardboard cut-out of a corona girl.  He was dancing with her, talking to her, offering her beer... basically in his own world.  His dramatic exit included him yelling, "F**k y'all."

If you're coming for karaoke, some things you should know:

There are only two song books.   They're listed by song title and don't specify the artist.  This can be problematic when you come across the song, Mother.  Is it Danzig or is it John Lennon?  It's Lennon.  Or when you pick the song Escape thinking it's the pina colada song... it's not.  It's actually the Enrique Iglesias song.

The songs are all midi music and barely audible over the vocals.

3 stars instead of 4 because they skipped my friends who were next to sing Rainbow Connection, twice!  and because they allow smoking at the bar
author: Jasmine W.

description: This place is surreal.  Drinking shots with Mama, listening to bi-lingual karaoke, talking about big "fish" with your newest Burmese drinking buddy.  Five star fun, followed by a five star hangover!
author: Nigel G.

description: Who knew I'd become a fan of dive bar! Mama is awesome! She not only filled our glasses to the rim while pouring a drink for herself to cheer with us, she also made sure our designated driver had her diet coke refilled constantly at no charge! Love Bow Bow!
author: V V.

description:
candy, oh candy..

if you are a fan of soap operas, or intense dramas, or comedys, or want to feel better about your own life, this is seriously the place for you. first, we walked in around 945-ish and candy, the bartender, was already drunk. she could still pour cocktails fairly correctly and has an ingenious version on a lemon drop shot, but when i asked for a "coors lite", i received "amstel"s instead. this repeated when i later ordered an "amstel" and received a "heineken". second, one of the customers there is obviously a regular. i saw photos of him on the wall in the same cheap leather bomber coat with aviators on he was wearing that night. he brought in some 'girlfriend' that night and she had issues. I-S-S-U-E-S, with capslock on. she was checking out her busted visage in the mirror wall constantly, yelling at candy for random things, and muttering to herself about "this bar is so odd...where am i anyway!?" she brought in a taxi driver who needed his fare for taking her somewhere and, upon her return, she went looking for joe cool in the aviators. he was in the restroom, so she went banging on the door, telling him to come out, and positioned the cab driver, like a present, in front of the door. it was surreal. when the woman demanded $7 from joe cool to give the cab driver, he told the cabbie to "get the hell out" before he knocked him out. thirdly, a few minutes after this, candy decides she wants to bang the gong. loudly. frequently. no idea what she was saying, but she was wearing the best "i'm wasted" smile with her eyes closed during the ordeal. fourthly, the karaoke machine had to have been found at a garage sale - the visuals of sunny mountain landscapes and lake vistas which partnered songs like iron maiden's MIDI version of "can i play with madness" was not to be expected. i think i did a triple take..

each of those events were powerful enough on their own to make me love the bow bow, but combined like voltron, they were an unstoppable force ingraining this business on my psyche like a nightmare you want to keep returning to. oh, keep your eye on how much you drink - since candy gets wasted, your bill may or may not be representative of what you realistically consumed. also, it's tiny, so huge groups can be hard to manage. 

i'd come here again, but not for at least six months or so. i'm not sure how this could possibly be a regular joint for anyone..
author: Jeremiah W.

description: i felt like a BOSS here. this place is on a whole other level of awsome
author: The D.

description: This place totally rules.  It is the only bar that I have ever been to where I passed out on top of my little Jennye while singing a karaoke tune, and then promptly jumped up to find Candy handing me another fresh beer and a shot of whisky.  This was after I already got 86'd from Specs across the street for being drunk and disorderly, so yes this place is pure magic.  Folsom will play you a song of your choice, but only if you are nice to him, so be nice to Folsom!!  Any of you naysayers that think it's a scary place just don't know the real deal, because Candy has been flinging cocktails at me for as long as I remember, way back into the late 80s/early 90s.  And she's now in her 20th year of business so I will always feel at home there, she always remembers me and knows exactly what I want drink, no matter how long it's been since my last visit.  Do not miss a visit to this classic hole in the wall, tell Candy I said YOU WANT A BUDWEISER??
author: Barbra K.

description: i finally sang karaoke in public.  for trivia buffs, i debuted with huey lewis' "power of love"...
author: Tim G.

description:
the first time i ventured into this glorious joint was serendipitously on chinese new year's eve. it was totally perfect. 
as soon as i walked in, i knew i was in love. the waried faces of chinese men hunched over their drinks turned to greet us with their grissled countenances and cigs dangling out of their mouths. a tiny, narrow bar with festive red walls (and a mirrored one, so you can check yourself out while belting out old tunes), this is a charming, oldschool, hardcore place with tons of character. candy wore a lowcut top and lace nighty jacket thing. and believe me, she was the perfect candy. she calls everyone "honey" and "sweetheart," and dishes out perfectly homemade chinese boiled peanuts (ru shui hua sheng, "only on the weekends") from her secret stash. in addition, there are sunflower seeds, roasted peanuts, and pistachios. perfect robust bites for the gritty but sweet atmosphere. fosin is a skinny, dear man with a hipster haircut; he watches over his beloved karoake machine with much affection. and man, when this chap sang "ladies night," i almost suffered an aneurysm of cuteness. 
i don't go out much, and usually hate bars, but i'll never forget my time here. i'll always go back to candy and fosin. they alone are worth the trip.
author: jennifer y.

description: I was going to give it 4 stars but then thought again about the place.  Don't expect this place to be like the Ritz Carlton of bars.  This place is more like a Motel 6 or a Travel Lodge so it can only be as good as the best Motel 6 or the best Travel Lodge.  Just know that much and you'll have a good time here.  Candy, the proprieter/bartender is great if you can understand half of what she's saying.  Folsom is the old man who is the resident "DJ" if you would.  He sings the best Ebony and Ivory (and he's a chinese guy) as well as some Bruce Springstein songs.  If he was 30 years younger he might have a shot at American Idol.  Drinks aren't dirt cheap but karaoke is free, however you usually have to put in your request early and not mind waiting.  And usually so many people will want to sing with you that if you ever want to sing a song solo, don't come here.  Also, don't sing the romantic songs here.  It will bring down the mood to this place like someone's puppy died.  If you can speak mandarin, a few words goes a long ways here.  As for the smoking, the no smoking law is to prevent employees from being exposed to second hand smoke since they don't have a choice if smoking was legal.  However, a business is exempt if they have 5 or less employees. Boo yah!
author: Benny M.

description: My favorite bar in SF.  12 stools and a bar.  Candy Wong is super friendly.  Buy her a shot of Hennessey and you'll be friends for life.  Fosin (the bar back) drinks brandy and water, just in case you lose 2 out of 3 in 24.  And expect to hear him sing "Satisfaction" at least twice a night.  I like this place earlier on before the packs arrive to sing two songs and leave, but then again I'm a bit of a karaoke hog.
author: Nate B.

description: I was initially hesitant when I stepped into the place. I guess I was envisioning one of those Korean or Japanese karaoke lounges where everyone has their own separate room. Definitely not a narrow stretch of room half of which is filled by the bar counter and with only a tiny karaoke set up at the very far end right next to the toilet. However, no one told me about the mandatory couple of Tsingtao's I was required to down before this place became like my personal shower singalong sessions. I think the charm of this place comes from not giving two hoots about how bad people are singing or how awfully wrong the lyrics being display across the screen are (especially Eye of the Tiger. Don't say I didn't warn you). I can say that I definitely had a blast and if you know Cantonese or Mandarin then you have the added advantage of singing something that maybe only the people behind the counter will be able to laugh at you for.
author: Yan Biao B.

description: this is one of my top 5 bars in the city. you can roll in there with 5 friends and own the joint
author: C.Edward K.

description:
This place just plain rocks.

The Bow Bow is a very acquired taste, but if you like super dives, you're in for a treat. If you like super dive bars with a Karaoke machine, this is about as good as it gets. The bartender (Candy i think is her name?) is one of the coolest bar tenders out there. Chat her up for a while and she'll be happy to pour an occasional shot on the house and slip you a bowl of peanuts. The dude running the Karaoke machine is a trip and runs a tight ship...trust me, he WILL yank the microphone out of your hands after he reaches his limit of your impromptu vulgarities...mid song. Finding a specific song in the song book is kind of like finding a straight man in the Castro. Your best bet is to go page by page until you actually find a song that you could possibly pull off, but then again, "pulling the song off" is no fun. I didn't witness it, but I've heard a great story of Candy chasing a patron down the street with a baseball bat, so don't push her...you might get clubbed like a sea lion. If you haven't been here, and this sounds good, you owe it to yourself to check this place out.
author: Robert T.

description: This place is really divey but had a blast there. The bartender Candy Ma Ma looks like a Thai transvestite and is missing a few teeth. She serves you peanuts and encourages everyone to take shots. Her bar back looks like he's a hundred years old and hobbles. The strip poker machine is scary. But by the end of the night I was drunk, singing Karma Chameleon and loving it.
author: foodbot c.
